It was marked by <a href="/wiki/Montagu%E2%80%93Chelmsford_Reforms" title="Montagu–Chelmsford Reforms">British reforms</a> but also <a href="/wiki/Rowlatt_act" class="mw-redirect" title="Rowlatt act">repressive legislation</a>, by more strident Indian calls for self-rule, and by the beginnings of a <a href="/wiki/Nonviolent" class="mw-redirect" title="Nonviolent">nonviolent</a> movement of non-co-operation, of which <a href="/wiki/Mohandas_Karamchand_Gandhi" class="mw-redirect" title="Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi">Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi</a> would become the leader and enduring symbol.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006167_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006167-160">[152]</a></sup> During the 1930s, slow legislative reform was enacted by the British; the Indian National Congress won victories in the resulting elections.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006195–197_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006195–197-161">[153]</a></sup> The next decade was beset with crises: <a href="/wiki/India_in_World_War_II" title="India in World War II">Indian participation in World War&nbsp;II</a>, the Congress's final push for non-co-operation, and an upsurge of Muslim nationalism. All were capped by the advent of independence in 1947, but tempered by the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">partition of India</a> into two states: India and Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006203_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006203-162">[154]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Vital to India's self-image as an independent nation was its constitution, completed in 1950, which put in place a secular and democratic republic.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006231_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006231-163">[155]</a></sup> It has remained a democracy with civil liberties, an active Supreme Court, and a largely independent press.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006265–266_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006265–266-164">[156]</a></sup> Economic liberalisation, which began in the 1990s, has created a large urban middle class, transformed India into <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(real)_growth_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by GDP (real) growth rate">one of the world's fastest-growing economies</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_States_Department_of_Agriculture_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_States_Department_of_Agriculture-165">[157]</a></sup> and increased its geopolitical clout. Indian movies, music, and spiritual teachings play an increasing role in global culture.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006265–266_164-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006265–266-164">[156]</a></sup> Yet, India is also shaped by seemingly unyielding poverty, both rural and urban;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006265–266_164-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006265–266-164">[156]</a></sup> by <a href="/wiki/Religious_violence_in_India" title="Religious violence in India">religious</a> and <a href="/wiki/Caste-related_violence_in_India" title="Caste-related violence in India">caste-related violence</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006266–270_166-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006266–270-166">[158]</a></sup> by <a href="/wiki/Naxalite" title="Naxalite">Maoist-inspired Naxalite insurgencies</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006253_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006253-167">[159]</a></sup> and by <a href="/wiki/Insurgency_in_Jammu_and_Kashmir" title="Insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir">separatism in Jammu and Kashmir</a> and <a href="/wiki/Insurgency_in_Northeast_India" title="Insurgency in Northeast India">in Northeast India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006274_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006274-168">[160]</a></sup> It has unresolved territorial disputes with <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93India_relations#1960s" title="China–India relations">China</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006247–248_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006247–248-169">[161]</a></sup> and with <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_wars_and_conflicts" title="Indo-Pakistani wars and conflicts">Pakistan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006247–248_169-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006247–248-169">[161]</a></sup> India's sustained democratic freedoms are unique among the world's newer nations; however, in spite of its recent economic successes, freedom from want for its disadvantaged population remains a goal yet to be achieved.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006304_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006304-170">[162]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_India" title="Geography of India">Geography of India</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;max-width:352px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:201px;max-width:201px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:164px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:India_Orographical_Features_Plate_4,_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India,_Atlas,_1909.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/India_Orographical_Features_Plate_4%2C_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India%2C_Atlas%2C_1909.jpg/199px-India_Orographical_Features_Plate_4%2C_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India%2C_Atlas%2C_1909.jpg" decoding="async" width="199" height="164" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/India_Orographical_Features_Plate_4%2C_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India%2C_Atlas%2C_1909.jpg/299px-India_Orographical_Features_Plate_4%2C_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India%2C_Atlas%2C_1909.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/India_Orographical_Features_Plate_4%2C_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India%2C_Atlas%2C_1909.jpg/398px-India_Orographical_Features_Plate_4%2C_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India%2C_Atlas%2C_1909.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3065" data-file-height="2532"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           India's <a href="/wiki/Orographic" class="mw-redirect" title="Orographic">orographical</a> features
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:147px;max-width:147px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:164px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:India_southwest_summer_monsoon_onset_map_en.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/India_southwest_summer_monsoon_onset_map_en.svg/145px-India_southwest_summer_monsoon_onset_map_en.svg.png" decoding="async" width="145" height="164" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/India_southwest_summer_monsoon_onset_map_en.svg/218px-India_southwest_summer_monsoon_onset_map_en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/India_southwest_summer_monsoon_onset_map_en.svg/290px-India_southwest_summer_monsoon_onset_map_en.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1639" data-file-height="1852"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           India's summer monsoon
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:350px;max-width:350px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:206px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Parked_boats_at_Anjarle_Creek.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Parked_boats_at_Anjarle_Creek.jpg/348px-Parked_boats_at_Anjarle_Creek.jpg" decoding="async" width="348" height="206" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Parked_boats_at_Anjarle_Creek.jpg/522px-Parked_boats_at_Anjarle_Creek.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Parked_boats_at_Anjarle_Creek.jpg/696px-Parked_boats_at_Anjarle_Creek.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4094" data-file-height="2428"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Fishing boats lashed together before a monsoon storm in a <a href="/wiki/Creek_(tidal)" class="mw-redirect" title="Creek (tidal)">tidal creek</a> in <a href="/wiki/Anjarle" title="Anjarle">Anjarle</a> village, Maharashtra.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>India accounts for the bulk of the Indian subcontinent, lying atop the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Plate" title="Indian Plate">Indian tectonic plate</a>, a part of the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Australian_Plate" title="Indo-Australian Plate">Indo-Australian Plate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005-171">[163]</a></sup> India's defining geological processes began 75 million years ago when the Indian Plate, then part of the southern supercontinent <a href="/wiki/Gondwana" title="Gondwana">Gondwana</a>, began a north-eastward <a href="/wiki/Plate_tectonics" title="Plate tectonics">drift</a> caused by <a href="/wiki/Seafloor_spreading" title="Seafloor spreading">seafloor spreading</a> to its south-west, and later, south and south-east.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005_171-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005-171">[163]</a></sup> Simultaneously, the vast <a href="/wiki/Tethys_Ocean" title="Tethys Ocean">Tethyan</a> <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_crust" title="Oceanic crust">oceanic crust</a>, to its northeast, began to <a href="/wiki/Subduction" title="Subduction">subduct</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Plate" title="Eurasian Plate">Eurasian Plate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005_171-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005-171">[163]</a></sup> These dual processes, driven by convection in the Earth's <a href="/wiki/Mantle_(geology)" title="Mantle (geology)">mantle</a>, both created the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a> and caused the Indian <a href="/wiki/Continental_crust" title="Continental crust">continental crust</a> eventually to under-thrust Eurasia and to uplift the <a href="/wiki/Himalayas" title="Himalayas">Himalayas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005_171-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005-171">[163]</a></sup> Immediately south of the emerging Himalayas, plate movement created a vast <a href="/wiki/Trough_(geology)" title="Trough (geology)">trough</a> that rapidly filled with river-borne sediment<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg7_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg7-172">[164]</a></sup> and now constitutes the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Gangetic_Plain" title="Indo-Gangetic Plain">Indo-Gangetic Plain</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPrakash_et_al.2000_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPrakash_et_al.2000-173">[165]</a></sup> Cut off from the plain by the ancient <a href="/wiki/Aravalli_Range" title="Aravalli Range">Aravalli Range</a> lies the <a href="/wiki/Thar_Desert" title="Thar Desert">Thar Desert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg11_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg11-174">[166]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The original Indian Plate survives as <a href="/wiki/South_India" title="South India">peninsular India</a>, the oldest and geologically most stable part of India. It extends as far north as the <a href="/wiki/Satpura_Range" title="Satpura Range">Satpura</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vindhya_Range" title="Vindhya Range">Vindhya</a> ranges in central India. These parallel chains run from the Arabian Sea coast in Gujarat in the west to the coal-rich <a href="/wiki/Chota_Nagpur_Plateau" title="Chota Nagpur Plateau">Chota Nagpur Plateau</a> in Jharkhand in the east.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg8_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg8-175">[167]</a></sup> To the south, the remaining peninsular landmass, the <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Plateau" title="Deccan Plateau">Deccan Plateau</a>, is flanked on the west and east by coastal ranges known as the <a href="/wiki/Western_Ghats" title="Western Ghats">Western</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Ghats" title="Eastern Ghats">Eastern Ghats</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg9–10_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg9–10-176">[168]</a></sup> the plateau contains the country's oldest rock formations, some over one billion years old. Constituted in such fashion, India lies to the north of the equator between 6° 44′ and 35° 30′ north latitude<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[i]</a></sup> and 68° 7′ and 97° 25′ east longitude.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Information_and_Broadcasting20071_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Information_and_Broadcasting20071-178">[169]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>India's coastline measures 7,517 kilometres (4,700&nbsp;mi) in length; of this distance, 5,423 kilometres (3,400&nbsp;mi) belong to peninsular India and 2,094 kilometres (1,300&nbsp;mi) to the Andaman, Nicobar, and Lakshadweep island chains.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKumarPathakPednekarRaju2006_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKumarPathakPednekarRaju2006-179">[170]</a></sup> According to the Indian naval hydrographic charts, the mainland coastline consists of the following: 43% sandy beaches; 11% rocky shores, including cliffs; and 46% <a href="/wiki/Mudflat" title="Mudflat">mudflats</a> or marshy shores.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKumarPathakPednekarRaju2006_179-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKumarPathakPednekarRaju2006-179">[170]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:124px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Tungabhadra_River_and_Coracle_Boats.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Tungabhadra_River_and_Coracle_Boats.JPG/208px-Tungabhadra_River_and_Coracle_Boats.JPG" decoding="async" width="208" height="125" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Tungabhadra_River_and_Coracle_Boats.JPG/312px-Tungabhadra_River_and_Coracle_Boats.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Tungabhadra_River_and_Coracle_Boats.JPG/416px-Tungabhadra_River_and_Coracle_Boats.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3857" data-file-height="2313"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Tungabhadra_river" class="mw-redirect" title="Tungabhadra river">Tungabhadra</a>, with rocky outcrops, flows into the peninsular <a href="/wiki/Krishna_river" class="mw-redirect" title="Krishna river">Krishna river</a>.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p><sup id="cite_ref-McgrailBlue2003_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McgrailBlue2003-180">[171]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Major Himalayan-origin rivers that substantially flow through India include the <a href="/wiki/Ganges" title="Ganges">Ganges</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Brahmaputra_River" title="Brahmaputra River">Brahmaputra</a>, both of which drain into the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal" title="Bay of Bengal">Bay of Bengal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg15_181-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg15-181">[172]</a></sup> Important tributaries of the Ganges include the <a href="/wiki/Yamuna" title="Yamuna">Yamuna</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kosi_River" title="Kosi River">Kosi</a>; the latter's extremely low gradient, caused by long-term silt deposition, leads to severe floods and course changes.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDuff1993353_182-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDuff1993353-182">[173]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BasuSJ2017-text_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BasuSJ2017-text-183">[174]</a></sup> Major peninsular rivers, whose steeper gradients prevent their waters from flooding, include the <a href="/wiki/Godavari_River" title="Godavari River">Godavari</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mahanadi_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Mahanadi River">Mahanadi</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kaveri_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Kaveri River">Kaveri</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Krishna_River" title="Krishna River">Krishna</a>, which also drain into the Bay of Bengal;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg16_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg16-184">[175]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Narmada_River" title="Narmada River">Narmada</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Tapti_River" title="Tapti River">Tapti</a>, which drain into the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">Arabian Sea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg17_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg17-185">[176]</a></sup> Coastal features include the marshy <a href="/wiki/Rann_of_Kutch" title="Rann of Kutch">Rann of Kutch</a> of western India and the alluvial <a href="/wiki/Sundarbans" title="Sundarbans">Sundarbans</a> delta of eastern India; the latter is shared with Bangladesh.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg12_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg12-186">[177]</a></sup> India has two <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelagos</a>: the <a href="/wiki/Lakshadweep" title="Lakshadweep">Lakshadweep</a>, <a href="/wiki/Atoll" title="Atoll">coral atolls</a> off India's south-western coast; and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, a volcanic chain in the <a href="/wiki/Andaman_Sea" title="Andaman Sea">Andaman Sea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg13_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshit_&amp;_Schwartzberg13-187">[178]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_India" title="Climate of India">Indian climate</a> is strongly influenced by the Himalayas and the Thar Desert, both of which drive the economically and culturally pivotal summer and winter <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoons</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChang1967391–394_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChang1967391–394-188">[179]</a></sup> The Himalayas prevent cold Central Asian <a href="/wiki/Katabatic_wind" title="Katabatic wind">katabatic winds</a> from blowing in, keeping the bulk of the Indian subcontinent warmer than most locations at similar latitudes.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPosey1994118_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPosey1994118-189">[180]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWolpert20034_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWolpert20034-190">[181]</a></sup> The Thar Desert plays a crucial role in attracting the moisture-laden south-west summer monsoon winds that, between June and October, provide the majority of India's rainfall.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChang1967391–394_188-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChang1967391–394-188">[179]</a></sup> Four major climatic groupings predominate in India: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_India#Tropical_wet" title="Climate of India">tropical wet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_India#Tropical_dry" title="Climate of India">tropical dry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_India#Subtropical_humid" title="Climate of India">subtropical humid</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_India#Mountain" title="Climate of India">montane</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHeitzmanWorden199697_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeitzmanWorden199697-191">[182]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Forestry_in_India" title="Forestry in India">Forestry in India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_India" title="Wildlife of India">Wildlife of India</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;max-width:352px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:199px;max-width:199px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:162px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:India_Vegetation_Features_IGI_1909_Atlas.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/India_Vegetation_Features_IGI_1909_Atlas.jpg/197px-India_Vegetation_Features_IGI_1909_Atlas.jpg" decoding="async" width="197" height="162" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/India_Vegetation_Features_IGI_1909_Atlas.jpg/296px-India_Vegetation_Features_IGI_1909_Atlas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/India_Vegetation_Features_IGI_1909_Atlas.jpg/394px-India_Vegetation_Features_IGI_1909_Atlas.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6141" data-file-height="5063"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           A 1909 map showing India's forests, bush and small wood, cultivated lands, steppe, and desert.
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:149px;max-width:149px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:162px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:2010_India_forest_cover_distribution_map_for_its_States_and_Union_Territories.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/2010_India_forest_cover_distribution_map_for_its_States_and_Union_Territories.svg/147px-2010_India_forest_cover_distribution_map_for_its_States_and_Union_Territories.svg.png" decoding="async" width="147" height="162" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/2010_India_forest_cover_distribution_map_for_its_States_and_Union_Territories.svg/221px-2010_India_forest_cover_distribution_map_for_its_States_and_Union_Territories.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/2010_India_forest_cover_distribution_map_for_its_States_and_Union_Territories.svg/294px-2010_India_forest_cover_distribution_map_for_its_States_and_Union_Territories.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1578" data-file-height="1738"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           A 2010 map showing India's forest cover averaged out for each state.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>India is a <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Megadiverse country">megadiverse country</a>, a term employed for 17 countries which display high <a href="/wiki/Biological_diversity" class="mw-redirect" title="Biological diversity">biological diversity</a> and contain many species exclusively <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_(ecology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Indigenous (ecology)">indigenous</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Endemic" class="mw-redirect" title="Endemic">endemic</a>, to them.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[183]</a></sup> India is a <a href="/wiki/Habitat" title="Habitat">habitat</a> for 8.6% of all <a href="/wiki/Mammal" title="Mammal">mammal</a> species, 13.7% of <a href="/wiki/Bird" title="Bird">bird</a> species, 7.9% of <a href="/wiki/Reptile" title="Reptile">reptile</a> species, 6% of <a href="/wiki/Amphibian" title="Amphibian">amphibian</a> species, 12.2% of <a href="/wiki/Fish" title="Fish">fish</a> species, and 6.0% of all <a href="/wiki/Flowering_plant" title="Flowering plant">flowering plant</a> species.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZoological_Survey_of_India20121_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZoological_Survey_of_India20121-193">[184]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPuri_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPuri-194">[185]</a></sup> Fully a third of Indian plant species are endemic.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBasak198324_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBasak198324-195">[186]</a></sup> India also contains four of the world's 34 <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_hotspot" title="Biodiversity hotspot">biodiversity hotspots</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-IUCN-India_66-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IUCN-India-66">[58]</a></sup> or regions that display significant habitat loss in the presence of high endemism.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[j]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SivaperumanVenkataraman2018_196-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SivaperumanVenkataraman2018-196">[187]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>India's <a href="/wiki/Forest_cover" title="Forest cover">forest cover</a> is 99,278&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (38,331&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), which is 21.67% of the country's total land area.<sup id="cite_ref-indiaforest_67-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-indiaforest-67">[59]</a></sup> It can be subdivided further into broad categories of <i>canopy density</i>, or the proportion of the area of a forest covered by its <a href="/wiki/Tree_canopy" class="mw-redirect" title="Tree canopy">tree canopy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Jha2018_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jha2018-198">[188]</a></sup> <i>Very dense forest</i>, whose <i>canopy density</i> is greater than 70%, occupies 3.02% of India's land area.<sup id="cite_ref-Jha2018_198-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jha2018-198">[188]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-indiaforest_67-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-indiaforest-67">[59]</a></sup> It predominates in the <a href="/wiki/Tropical_and_subtropical_moist_broadleaf_forest" class="mw-redirect" title="Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forest">tropical moist forest</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Andaman_Islands" title="Andaman Islands">Andaman Islands</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Western_Ghats" title="Western Ghats">Western Ghats</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Northeast_India" title="Northeast India">Northeast India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETritsch2001_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETritsch2001-199">[189]</a></sup> <i>Moderately dense forest</i>, whose canopy density is between 40% and 70%, occupies 9.39% of India's land area.<sup id="cite_ref-Jha2018_198-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jha2018-198">[188]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-indiaforest_67-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-indiaforest-67">[59]</a></sup> It predominates in the <a href="/wiki/Temperate_coniferous_forest" title="Temperate coniferous forest">temperate coniferous forest</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Himalaya" class="mw-redirect" title="Himalaya">Himalayas</a>, the moist deciduous <i><a href="/wiki/Shorea_robusta" title="Shorea robusta">sal</a></i> forest of eastern India, and the dry deciduous <a href="/wiki/Teak" title="Teak">teak</a> forest of central and southern India.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETritsch2001_199-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETritsch2001-199">[189]</a></sup> <i>Open forest</i>, whose canopy density is between 10% and 40%, occupies 9.26% of India's land area,<sup id="cite_ref-Jha2018_198-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jha2018-198">[188]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-indiaforest_67-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-indiaforest-67">[59]</a></sup> and predominates in the <a href="/wiki/Acacia_nilotica" class="mw-redirect" title="Acacia nilotica">babul</a>-dominated <a href="/wiki/Deserts_and_xeric_shrublands" title="Deserts and xeric shrublands">thorn forest</a> of the central <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Plateau" title="Deccan Plateau">Deccan Plateau</a> and the western <a href="/wiki/Gangetic_plain" class="mw-redirect" title="Gangetic plain">Gangetic plain</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETritsch2001_199-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETritsch2001-199">[189]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Among the Indian subcontinent's notable indigenous trees are the <a href="/wiki/Astringent" title="Astringent">astringent</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Azadirachta_indica" title="Azadirachta indica">Azadirachta indica</a></i>, or <i>neem</i>, which is widely used in rural Indian <a href="/wiki/Herbal_medicine" title="Herbal medicine">herbal medicine</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Goyal2006_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Goyal2006-200">[190]</a></sup> and the luxuriant <i><a href="/wiki/Ficus_religiosa" title="Ficus religiosa">Ficus religiosa</a></i>, or <i>peepul</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-Hughes2013_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hughes2013-201">[191]</a></sup> which is displayed on the ancient seals of <a href="/wiki/Mohenjo-daro" title="Mohenjo-daro">Mohenjo-daro</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-AmeriCostello2018_202-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AmeriCostello2018-202">[192]</a></sup> and under which <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">the Buddha</a> is recorded in the <a href="/wiki/Pali_canon" class="mw-redirect" title="Pali canon">Pali canon</a> to have sought enlightenment.<sup id="cite_ref-Gwynne2011_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gwynne2011-203">[193]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg/260px-Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="173" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg/390px-Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg/520px-Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4057" data-file-height="2705"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>India has the majority of the world's wild tigers, nearly 3,000 in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[194]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Many Indian species have descended from those of <a href="/wiki/Gondwana" title="Gondwana">Gondwana</a>, the southern <a href="/wiki/Supercontinent" title="Supercontinent">supercontinent</a> from which India separated more than 100 million years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrameOwen2002142_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrameOwen2002142-205">[195]</a></sup> India's subsequent collision with Eurasia set off a mass exchange of species. However, <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Traps" title="Deccan Traps">volcanism</a> and climatic changes later caused the extinction of many endemic Indian forms.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKaranth2006_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKaranth2006-206">[196]</a></sup> Still later, mammals entered India from Asia through two <a href="/wiki/Zoogeographical" class="mw-redirect" title="Zoogeographical">zoogeographical</a> passes flanking the Himalayas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETritsch2001_199-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETritsch2001-199">[189]</a></sup> This had the effect of lowering endemism among India's mammals, which stands at 12.6%, contrasting with 45.8% among reptiles and 55.8% among amphibians.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPuri_194-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPuri-194">[185]</a></sup> Notable endemics are the vulnerable<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[197]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nilgiri_Langur" class="mw-redirect" title="Nilgiri Langur">hooded leaf monkey</a><sup id="cite_ref-itis_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-itis-208">[198]</a></sup> and the threatened<sup id="cite_ref-IUCN_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IUCN-209">[199]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Duttaphrynus_beddomii" title="Duttaphrynus beddomii">Beddom's toad</a><sup id="cite_ref-IUCN_209-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IUCN-209">[199]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[200]</a></sup> of the Western Ghats. </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:138px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Axis_axis_(Nagarhole,_2010).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Axis_axis_%28Nagarhole%2C_2010%29.jpg/208px-Axis_axis_%28Nagarhole%2C_2010%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="139" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Axis_axis_%28Nagarhole%2C_2010%29.jpg/312px-Axis_axis_%28Nagarhole%2C_2010%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Axis_axis_%28Nagarhole%2C_2010%29.jpg/416px-Axis_axis_%28Nagarhole%2C_2010%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3200" data-file-height="2134"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           A <a href="/wiki/Chital" title="Chital">Chital</a> (<i>Axis axis</i>) stag attempts to browse in the <a href="/wiki/Nagarhole_National_Park" title="Nagarhole National Park">Nagarhole National Park</a> in a region covered by a <i>moderately dense</i><sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[k]</a></sup> forest.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETritsch2001_199-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETritsch2001-199">[189]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>India contains 172 <a href="/wiki/World_Conservation_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="World Conservation Union">IUCN</a>-designated <a href="/wiki/List_of_endangered_animals_in_India" title="List of endangered animals in India">threatened animal species</a>, or 2.9% of endangered forms.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMace19944_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMace19944-212">[201]</a></sup> These include the endangered <a href="/wiki/Bengal_tiger" title="Bengal tiger">Bengal tiger</a> and the <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_river_dolphin" title="South Asian river dolphin">Ganges river dolphin</a>. <a href="/wiki/Critically_endangered" class="mw-redirect" title="Critically endangered">Critically endangered</a> species include: the <a href="/wiki/Gharial" title="Gharial">gharial</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Crocodilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Crocodilian">crocodilian</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Great_Indian_bustard" title="Great Indian bustard">great Indian bustard</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/Indian_white-rumped_vulture" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian white-rumped vulture">Indian white-rumped vulture</a>, which has become nearly extinct by having ingested the carrion of <a href="/wiki/Diclofenac" title="Diclofenac">diclofenac</a>-treated cattle.<sup id="cite_ref-LovetteFitzpatrick2016_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LovetteFitzpatrick2016-213">[202]</a></sup> The pervasive and ecologically devastating human encroachment of recent decades has critically endangered Indian wildlife. In response, the system of <a href="/wiki/National_parks_of_India" class="mw-redirect" title="National parks of India">national parks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_India" title="Protected areas of India">protected areas</a>, first established in 1935, was expanded substantially. In 1972, India enacted the <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_Protection_Act_of_1972" class="mw-redirect" title="Wildlife Protection Act of 1972">Wildlife Protection Act</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Environments_and_Forests_1972_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Environments_and_Forests_1972-214">[203]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Project_Tiger" title="Project Tiger">Project Tiger</a> to safeguard crucial wilderness; the Forest Conservation Act was enacted in 1980 and amendments added in 1988.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Environment_and_Forests1988_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Environment_and_Forests1988-215">[204]</a></sup> India hosts <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_sanctuaries_of_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Wildlife sanctuaries of India">more than five hundred wildlife sanctuaries</a> and <a href="/wiki/Biosphere_reserves_of_India" title="Biosphere reserves of India">thirteen<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>biosphere reserves</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Environment_and_Forests_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Environment_and_Forests-216">[205]</a></sup> four of which are part of the <a href="/wiki/World_Network_of_Biosphere_Reserves" title="World Network of Biosphere Reserves">World Network of Biosphere Reserves</a>; <a href="/wiki/List_of_Ramsar_Sites_in_India" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Ramsar Sites in India">twenty-five wetlands</a> are registered under the <a href="/wiki/Ramsar_Convention" title="Ramsar Convention">Ramsar Convention</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESecretariat_of_the_Convention_on_Wetlands_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESecretariat_of_the_Convention_on_Wetlands-217">[206]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics_and_government">Politics and government</span></h2> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_India" title="Politics of India">Politics of India</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:138px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Rajagopal_speaking_to_25,000_people,_Janadesh_2007,_India.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Rajagopal_speaking_to_25%2C000_people%2C_Janadesh_2007%2C_India.jpg/208px-Rajagopal_speaking_to_25%2C000_people%2C_Janadesh_2007%2C_India.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="138" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Rajagopal_speaking_to_25%2C000_people%2C_Janadesh_2007%2C_India.jpg/312px-Rajagopal_speaking_to_25%2C000_people%2C_Janadesh_2007%2C_India.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Rajagopal_speaking_to_25%2C000_people%2C_Janadesh_2007%2C_India.jpg/416px-Rajagopal_speaking_to_25%2C000_people%2C_Janadesh_2007%2C_India.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Social_movement" title="Social movement">Social movements</a> have long been a part of <a href="/wiki/Democracy_in_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Democracy in India">democracy in India</a>. The picture shows a section of 25,000 <a href="/wiki/Landless" class="mw-redirect" title="Landless">landless</a> people in the state of <a href="/wiki/Madhya_Pradesh" title="Madhya Pradesh">Madhya Pradesh</a> listening to <a href="/wiki/Rajagopal_P._V." title="Rajagopal P. V.">Rajagopal P. V.</a> before their 350&nbsp;km (220&nbsp;mi) march, <a href="/wiki/Janadesh_2007" title="Janadesh 2007">Janadesh 2007</a>, from <a href="/wiki/Gwalior" title="Gwalior">Gwalior</a> to <a href="/wiki/New_Delhi" title="New Delhi">New Delhi</a> to publicise their demand for further <a href="/wiki/Land_reform_in_India" title="Land reform in India">land reform in India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Johnston2019_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Johnston2019-218">[207]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>India is the world's most populous <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democracy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations_Population_Division_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations_Population_Division-219">[208]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a> with a <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_system" title="Multi-party system">multi-party system</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBurnellCalvert1999125_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurnellCalvert1999125-220">[209]</a></sup> it has eight<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>recognised <a href="/wiki/List_of_recognised_political_parties_in_India#National" class="mw-redirect" title="List of recognised political parties in India">national parties</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">Indian National Congress</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party" title="Bharatiya Janata Party">Bharatiya Janata Party</a> (BJP), and more than 40<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/List_of_recognised_political_parties_in_India#State" class="mw-redirect" title="List of recognised political parties in India">regional parties</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElection_Commission_of_India_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElection_Commission_of_India-221">[210]</a></sup> The Congress is considered centre-left in Indian <a href="/wiki/Political_culture" title="Political culture">political culture</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[211]</a></sup> and the BJP <a href="/wiki/Right-wing_politics" title="Right-wing politics">right-wing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMalikSingh1992318–336_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMalikSingh1992318–336-223">[212]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBBC2012_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBBC2012-224">[213]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBanerjee20053118_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBanerjee20053118-225">[214]</a></sup> For most of the period between 1950—when India first became a republic—and the late 1980s, the Congress held a majority in the parliament. Since then, however, it has increasingly shared the political stage with the BJP,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarkar200784_226-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarkar200784-226">[215]</a></sup> as well as with powerful regional parties which have often forced the creation of multi-party <a href="/wiki/Coalition_government" title="Coalition government">coalition governments</a> at the centre.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChander2004117_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChander2004117-227">[216]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the Republic of India's first three general elections, in 1951, 1957, and 1962, the <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru" title="Jawaharlal Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a>-led Congress won easy victories. On Nehru's death in 1964, <a href="/wiki/Lal_Bahadur_Shastri" title="Lal Bahadur Shastri">Lal Bahadur Shastri</a> briefly became prime minister; he was succeeded, after his own unexpected death in 1966, by Nehru's daughter <a href="/wiki/Indira_Gandhi" title="Indira Gandhi">Indira Gandhi</a>, who went on to lead the Congress to election victories in 1967 and 1971. Following public discontent with the <a href="/wiki/The_Emergency_(India)" title="The Emergency (India)">state of emergency</a> she declared in 1975, the Congress was voted out of power in 1977; the then-new <a href="/wiki/Janata_Party" title="Janata Party">Janata Party</a>, which had opposed the emergency, was voted in. Its government lasted just over two years. Voted back into power in 1980, the Congress saw a change in leadership in 1984, when Indira Gandhi was assassinated; she was succeeded by her son <a href="/wiki/Rajiv_Gandhi" title="Rajiv Gandhi">Rajiv Gandhi</a>, who won an easy victory in the general elections later that year. The Congress was voted out again in 1989 when a <a href="/wiki/National_Front_(India)" title="National Front (India)">National Front</a> coalition, led by the newly formed <a href="/wiki/Janata_Dal" title="Janata Dal">Janata Dal</a> in alliance with the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_India_(Marxist)" title="Communist Party of India (Marxist)">Left Front</a>, won the elections; that government too proved relatively short-lived, lasting just under two years.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhambhri1992118,_143_228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhambhri1992118,_143-228">[217]</a></sup> Elections were held again in 1991; no party won an absolute majority. The Congress, as the largest single party, was able to form a <a href="/wiki/Minority_government" title="Minority government">minority government</a> led by <a href="/wiki/P._V._Narasimha_Rao" title="P. V. Narasimha Rao">P. V. Narasimha Rao</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[218]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:138px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_at_Parliament_of_India_in_New_Delhi_addressing_Joint_session_of_both_houses_2010.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Barack_Obama_at_Parliament_of_India_in_New_Delhi_addressing_Joint_session_of_both_houses_2010.jpg/208px-Barack_Obama_at_Parliament_of_India_in_New_Delhi_addressing_Joint_session_of_both_houses_2010.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="139" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Barack_Obama_at_Parliament_of_India_in_New_Delhi_addressing_Joint_session_of_both_houses_2010.jpg/312px-Barack_Obama_at_Parliament_of_India_in_New_Delhi_addressing_Joint_session_of_both_houses_2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Barack_Obama_at_Parliament_of_India_in_New_Delhi_addressing_Joint_session_of_both_houses_2010.jpg/416px-Barack_Obama_at_Parliament_of_India_in_New_Delhi_addressing_Joint_session_of_both_houses_2010.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4096" data-file-height="2731"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           At the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_India" title="Parliament of India">Parliament of India</a> in New Delhi, US president <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> is shown here addressing the <a href="/wiki/Member_of_parliament_(India)" title="Member of parliament (India)">members of parliament</a> of both houses, the lower, <a href="/wiki/Lok_Sabha" title="Lok Sabha">Lok Sabha</a>, and the upper, <a href="/wiki/Rajya_Sabha" title="Rajya Sabha">Rajya Sabha</a>, in a joint session, 8 November 2010.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>A two-year period of political turmoil followed the general election of 1996. Several short-lived alliances shared power at the centre. The BJP formed a government briefly in 1996; it was followed by two comparatively long-lasting <a href="/wiki/United_Front_(India)" title="United Front (India)">United Front</a> coalitions, which depended on external support. In 1998, the BJP was able to form a successful coalition, the <a href="/wiki/National_Democratic_Alliance" title="National Democratic Alliance">National Democratic Alliance</a> (NDA). Led by <a href="/wiki/Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee" title="Atal Bihari Vajpayee">Atal Bihari Vajpayee</a>, the NDA became the first non-Congress, <a href="/wiki/Coalition_government" title="Coalition government">coalition government</a> to complete a five-year term.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDunleavyDiwakarDunleavy2007_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDunleavyDiwakarDunleavy2007-230">[219]</a></sup> Again in the <a href="/wiki/2004_Indian_general_election" title="2004 Indian general election">2004 Indian general elections</a>, no party won an absolute majority, but the Congress emerged as the largest single party, forming another successful coalition: the <a href="/wiki/United_Progressive_Alliance" title="United Progressive Alliance">United Progressive Alliance</a> (UPA). It had the support of left-leaning parties and MPs who opposed the BJP. The UPA returned to power in the <a href="/wiki/2009_Indian_general_election" title="2009 Indian general election">2009 general election</a> with increased numbers, and it no longer required external support from <a href="/wiki/Socialism_in_India" title="Socialism in India">India's communist parties</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund2004384_231-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund2004384-231">[220]</a></sup> That year, <a href="/wiki/Manmohan_Singh" title="Manmohan Singh">Manmohan Singh</a> became the first prime minister since <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru" title="Jawaharlal Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a> in <a href="/wiki/1957_Indian_general_election" title="1957 Indian general election">1957</a> and <a href="/wiki/1962_Indian_general_election" title="1962 Indian general election">1962</a> to be re-elected to a consecutive five-year term.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBusiness_Standard2009_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBusiness_Standard2009-232">[221]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/2014_Indian_general_election" title="2014 Indian general election">2014 general election</a>, the BJP became the first political party since 1984 to win a majority and govern without the support of other parties.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[222]</a></sup> The incumbent prime minister is <a href="/wiki/Narendra_Modi" title="Narendra Modi">Narendra Modi</a>, a former <a href="/wiki/Chief_minister_(India)" title="Chief minister (India)">chief minister</a> of <a href="/wiki/Gujarat" title="Gujarat">Gujarat</a>. On 20 July 2017, <a href="/wiki/Ram_Nath_Kovind" title="Ram Nath Kovind">Ram Nath Kovind</a> was elected India's 14th president and took the oath of office on 25 July 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[223]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[224]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[225]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India" title="Government of India">Government of India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_India" title="Constitution of India">Constitution of India</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:138px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Rashtrapati_Bhavan_Wide_New_Delhi_India.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Rashtrapati_Bhavan_Wide_New_Delhi_India.jpg/208px-Rashtrapati_Bhavan_Wide_New_Delhi_India.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="138" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Rashtrapati_Bhavan_Wide_New_Delhi_India.jpg/312px-Rashtrapati_Bhavan_Wide_New_Delhi_India.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Rashtrapati_Bhavan_Wide_New_Delhi_India.jpg/416px-Rashtrapati_Bhavan_Wide_New_Delhi_India.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2710" data-file-height="1798"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Rashtrapati_Bhavan" title="Rashtrapati Bhavan">Rashtrapati Bhavan</a>, the official residence of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_India" title="President of India">President of India</a>, was designed by British architects <a href="/wiki/Edwin_Lutyens" title="Edwin Lutyens">Edwin Lutyens</a> and <a href="/wiki/Herbert_Baker" title="Herbert Baker">Herbert Baker</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Viceroy_of_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Viceroy of India">Viceroy of India</a>, and constructed between 1911 and 1931 during the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bremner2016_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bremner2016-237">[226]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>India is a <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federation</a> with a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary system</a> governed under the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_India" title="Constitution of India">Constitution of India</a>—the country's supreme legal document. It is a constitutional republic and <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative democracy</a>, in which "<a href="/wiki/Majority_rule" title="Majority rule">majority rule</a> is tempered by <a href="/wiki/Minority_rights" title="Minority rights">minority rights</a> protected by <a href="/wiki/Law_of_India" title="Law of India">law</a>". <a href="/wiki/Federalism_in_India" title="Federalism in India">Federalism in India</a> defines the power distribution between the union and the <a href="/wiki/States_and_territories_of_India" class="mw-redirect" title="States and territories of India">states</a>. The Constitution of India, which came into effect on 26 January 1950,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPylee2003a4_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPylee2003a4-238">[227]</a></sup> originally stated India to be a "<a href="/wiki/Sovereign" title="Sovereign">sovereign</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liberal_democracy" title="Liberal democracy">democratic</a> <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republic</a>;" this characterisation was amended in 1971 to "a sovereign, socialist, <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secular</a>, democratic republic".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDutt1998421_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDutt1998421-239">[228]</a></sup> India's form of government, traditionally described as "quasi-federal" with a strong centre and weak states,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWheare198028_240-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWheare198028-240">[229]</a></sup> has grown increasingly federal since the late 1990s as a result of political, economic, and social changes.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEcheverri-Gent200219–20_241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEcheverri-Gent200219–20-241">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESinha200425_242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESinha200425-242">[231]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="infobox">
       <caption class="infobox-title" style="font-size:120%;">

      </table> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India" title="Government of India">Government of India</a> comprises three branches:<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[233]</a></sup> </p> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">Executive</a>: The <a href="/wiki/President_of_India" title="President of India">President of India</a> is the ceremonial <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma200731_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma200731-245">[234]</a></sup> who is elected indirectly for a five-year term by an <a href="/wiki/Electoral_College_(India)" title="Electoral College (India)">electoral college</a> comprising members of national and state legislatures.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma2007138_246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007138-246">[235]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGledhill1970112_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGledhill1970112-247">[236]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India" title="Prime Minister of India">Prime Minister of India</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a> and exercises most <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executive power</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma1950_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma1950-248">[237]</a></sup> Appointed by the president,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma2007162_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007162-249">[238]</a></sup> the prime minister is by convention supported by the <a href="/wiki/Political_party" title="Political party">party</a> or <a href="/wiki/Political_alliance" title="Political alliance">political alliance</a> having a majority of seats in the lower house of parliament.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma1950_248-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma1950-248">[237]</a></sup> The executive of the Indian government consists of the president, the <a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_India" title="Vice President of India">vice president</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Union_Council_of_Ministers" title="Union Council of Ministers">Union Council of Ministers</a>—with the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_(government)" title="Cabinet (government)">cabinet</a> being its executive committee—headed by the prime minister. Any minister holding a portfolio must be a member of one of the houses of parliament.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma200731_245-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma200731-245">[234]</a></sup> In the Indian parliamentary system, the executive is subordinate to the legislature; the prime minister and their council are directly responsible to the lower house of the parliament. <a href="/wiki/Civil_Services_of_India" title="Civil Services of India">Civil servants</a> act as permanent executives and all decisions of the <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executive</a> are implemented by them.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMathew2003524_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMathew2003524-250">[239]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">Legislature</a>: The legislature of India is the <a href="/wiki/Bicameralism" title="Bicameralism">bicameral</a> <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_India" title="Parliament of India">parliament</a>. Operating under a <a href="/wiki/Westminster_system" title="Westminster system">Westminster-style</a> parliamentary system, it comprises an upper house called the <a href="/wiki/Rajya_Sabha" title="Rajya Sabha">Rajya Sabha</a> (Council of States) and a lower house called the <a href="/wiki/Lok_Sabha" title="Lok Sabha">Lok Sabha</a> (House of the People).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGledhill1970127_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGledhill1970127-251">[240]</a></sup> The Rajya Sabha is a permanent body of 245<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>members who serve staggered six-year<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>terms.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma2007161_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007161-252">[241]</a></sup> Most are elected indirectly by the <a href="/wiki/States_and_union_territories_of_India" title="States and union territories of India">state and union territorial</a> legislatures in numbers proportional to their state's share of the national population.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma2007162_249-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007162-249">[238]</a></sup> All but two of the Lok Sabha's 545<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>members are elected directly by popular vote; they represent <a href="/wiki/Single-member_constituency" class="mw-redirect" title="Single-member constituency">single-member constituencies</a> for five-year<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>terms.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma2007143_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007143-253">[242]</a></sup> Two seats of parliament, reserved for <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Indian" title="Anglo-Indian">Anglo-Indian</a> in the article 331, have been scrapped.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[243]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[244]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">Judiciary</a>: India has a three-tier<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>unitary <a href="/wiki/Judicial_independence" title="Judicial independence">independent judiciary</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENeuborne2003478_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeuborne2003478-256">[245]</a></sup> comprising the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India" title="Supreme Court of India">supreme court</a>, headed by the <a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_India" title="Chief Justice of India">Chief Justice of India</a>, 25<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/High_courts_of_India" title="High courts of India">high courts</a>, and a large number of trial courts.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENeuborne2003478_256-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeuborne2003478-256">[245]</a></sup> The supreme court has <a href="/wiki/Original_jurisdiction" title="Original jurisdiction">original jurisdiction</a> over cases involving <a href="/wiki/Fundamental_rights_in_India" title="Fundamental rights in India">fundamental rights</a> and over disputes between states and the centre and has <a href="/wiki/Appellate_jurisdiction" title="Appellate jurisdiction">appellate jurisdiction</a> over the high courts.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma2007238,_255_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007238,_255-257">[246]</a></sup> It has the power to both strike down union or state laws which contravene the constitution,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESripati1998423–424_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESripati1998423–424-258">[247]</a></sup> and invalidate any government action it deems unconstitutional.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPylee2003b314_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPylee2003b314-259">[248]</a></sup></li>
      </ul> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_India" title="Administrative divisions of India">Administrative divisions of India</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Political_integration_of_India" title="Political integration of India">Political integration of India</a>
      </div> 
      <p>India is a federal union comprising 28 <a href="/wiki/States_and_union_territories_of_India" title="States and union territories of India">states</a> and 8 <a href="/wiki/Union_territory" title="Union territory">union territories</a> (listed below as 1–28 and A–H, respectively).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress2004_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress2004-260">[249]</a></sup> All states, as well as the union territories of <a href="/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(union_territory)" title="Jammu and Kashmir (union territory)">Jammu and Kashmir</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puducherry_(union_territory)" title="Puducherry (union territory)">Puducherry</a> and the <a href="/wiki/National_Capital_Territory_of_Delhi" class="mw-redirect" title="National Capital Territory of Delhi">National Capital Territory of Delhi</a>, have elected legislatures and governments following the Westminster system of governance. The remaining five union territories are directly ruled by the central government through appointed administrators. In 1956, under the <a href="/wiki/States_Reorganisation_Act,_1956" title="States Reorganisation Act, 1956">States Reorganisation Act</a>, states were reorganised on a linguistic basis.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma200749_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma200749-261">[250]</a></sup> There are over a quarter of a million local government bodies at city, town, block, district and village levels.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[251]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:382px;">
        <div class="noresize">
         <map name="ImageMap_ac9e496eb2fed19f"><area href="/wiki/Afghanistan" shape="rect" coords="0,41,64,48" alt="Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan"><area href="/wiki/Myanmar" shape="rect" alt="Uttar Pradesh" title="Uttar Pradesh"><area href="/wiki/Uttarakhand" shape="poly"         </div>

      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h2><span id="Foreign.2C_economic_and_strategic_relations"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign,_economic_and_strategic_relations">Foreign, economic and strategic relations</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_India" title="Foreign relations of India">Foreign relations of India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indian_Armed_Forces" title="Indian Armed Forces">Indian Armed Forces</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:130px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Jawaharlal_Nehru,_Nasser_and_Tito_at_the_Conference_of_Non-Aligned_Nations_held_in_Belgrade.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Jawaharlal_Nehru%2C_Nasser_and_Tito_at_the_Conference_of_Non-Aligned_Nations_held_in_Belgrade.jpg/208px-Jawaharlal_Nehru%2C_Nasser_and_Tito_at_the_Conference_of_Non-Aligned_Nations_held_in_Belgrade.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="130" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Jawaharlal_Nehru%2C_Nasser_and_Tito_at_the_Conference_of_Non-Aligned_Nations_held_in_Belgrade.jpg/312px-Jawaharlal_Nehru%2C_Nasser_and_Tito_at_the_Conference_of_Non-Aligned_Nations_held_in_Belgrade.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Jawaharlal_Nehru%2C_Nasser_and_Tito_at_the_Conference_of_Non-Aligned_Nations_held_in_Belgrade.jpg/416px-Jawaharlal_Nehru%2C_Nasser_and_Tito_at_the_Conference_of_Non-Aligned_Nations_held_in_Belgrade.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="400"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           During the 1950s and 60s, India played a pivotal role in the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Dinkel2018_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dinkel2018-263">[252]</a></sup> From left to right: <a href="/wiki/Gamal_Abdel_Nasser" title="Gamal Abdel Nasser">Gamal Abdel Nasser</a> of <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Republic" title="United Arab Republic">United Arab Republic</a> (now Egypt), <a href="/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito" title="Josip Broz Tito">Josip Broz Tito</a> of <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavia" title="Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru" title="Jawaharlal Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a> in Belgrade, September 1961.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In the 1950s, India strongly supported decolonisation in <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a> and <a href="/wiki/India_and_the_Non-Aligned_Movement" title="India and the Non-Aligned Movement">played a leading role</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERothermund200048,_227_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERothermund200048,_227-264">[253]</a></sup> After initially cordial relations with neighbouring China, India went to <a href="/wiki/Sino-Indian_War" title="Sino-Indian War">war with China in 1962</a>, and was widely thought to have been humiliated. India has had <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Pakistani relations">tense relations</a> with neighbouring Pakistan; the two nations have gone to war four times: in <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1947" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1947">1947</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1965" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1965">1965</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1971" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1971">1971</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kargil_War" title="Kargil War">1999</a>. Three of these wars were fought over the <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_conflict" title="Kashmir conflict">disputed territory of Kashmir</a>, while the fourth, the 1971 war, followed from India's support for the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="Bangladesh Liberation War">independence of Bangladesh</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGilbert2002486–487_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGilbert2002486–487-265">[254]</a></sup> In the late 1980s, the Indian military twice intervened abroad at the invitation of the host country: a <a href="/wiki/Indian_Peace_Keeping_Force" title="Indian Peace Keeping Force">peace-keeping operation</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a> between 1987 and 1990; and an armed intervention to prevent a <a href="/wiki/1988_Maldives_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" class="mw-redirect" title="1988 Maldives coup d'état">1988 coup d'état attempt</a> in the Maldives. After the 1965 war with Pakistan, India began to pursue close military and economic <a href="/wiki/India-Soviet_Union_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="India-Soviet Union relations">ties with the Soviet Union</a>; by the late 1960s, the Soviet Union was its largest arms supplier.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma199956_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma199956-266">[255]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Aside from ongoing its <a href="/wiki/India%E2%80%93Russia_relations" title="India–Russia relations">special relationship with Russia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[256]</a></sup> India has wide-ranging <a href="/wiki/India%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="India–Israel relations">defence relations with Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/France%E2%80%93India_relations" title="France–India relations">France</a>. In recent years, it has played key roles in the <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_Association_for_Regional_Cooperation" title="South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation">South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation</a> and the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>. The nation has provided 100,000 <a href="/wiki/Indian_Armed_Forces" title="Indian Armed Forces">military</a> and <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_India" title="Law enforcement in India">police</a> personnel to serve in 35 <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_peacekeeping" title="United Nations peacekeeping">UN peacekeeping operations</a> across four continents. It participates in the <a href="/wiki/East_Asia_Summit" title="East Asia Summit">East Asia Summit</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G8%2B5" title="G8+5">G8+5</a>, and other multilateral forums.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlford2008_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlford2008-268">[257]</a></sup> India has close economic ties with countries in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[258]</a></sup> Asia, and Africa; it pursues a <a href="/wiki/Look_East_policy_(India)" title="Look East policy (India)">"Look East" policy</a> that seeks to strengthen partnerships with the <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations" class="mw-redirect" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">ASEAN</a> nations, <a href="/wiki/India%E2%80%93Japan_relations" title="India–Japan relations">Japan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/India%E2%80%93South_Korea_relations" title="India–South Korea relations">South Korea</a> that revolve around many issues, but especially those involving economic investment and regional security.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGhosh2009282–289_270-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGhosh2009282–289-270">[259]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESisodiaNaidu20051–8_271-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESisodiaNaidu20051–8-271">[260]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:121px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Indian_Air_Force_contingent_as_a_part_of_the_Bastille_Day_Parade_of_France,_in_Paris_on_July_14,_2009.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Indian_Air_Force_contingent_as_a_part_of_the_Bastille_Day_Parade_of_France%2C_in_Paris_on_July_14%2C_2009.jpg/208px-Indian_Air_Force_contingent_as_a_part_of_the_Bastille_Day_Parade_of_France%2C_in_Paris_on_July_14%2C_2009.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="121" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Indian_Air_Force_contingent_as_a_part_of_the_Bastille_Day_Parade_of_France%2C_in_Paris_on_July_14%2C_2009.jpg/312px-Indian_Air_Force_contingent_as_a_part_of_the_Bastille_Day_Parade_of_France%2C_in_Paris_on_July_14%2C_2009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Indian_Air_Force_contingent_as_a_part_of_the_Bastille_Day_Parade_of_France%2C_in_Paris_on_July_14%2C_2009.jpg/416px-Indian_Air_Force_contingent_as_a_part_of_the_Bastille_Day_Parade_of_France%2C_in_Paris_on_July_14%2C_2009.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2100" data-file-height="1222"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Indian_Air_Force" title="Indian Air Force">Indian Air Force</a> contingent marching at the 221st <a href="/wiki/Bastille_Day_military_parade" title="Bastille Day military parade">Bastille Day military parade</a> in Paris, on 14 July 2009. The parade at which India was the foreign guest was led by the India's oldest regiment, the <a href="/wiki/Maratha_Light_Infantry" title="Maratha Light Infantry">Maratha Light Infantry</a>, founded in 1768.<sup id="cite_ref-guardian-muir-diary-maratha_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guardian-muir-diary-maratha-272">[261]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>China's <a href="/wiki/596_(nuclear_test)" class="mw-redirect" title="596 (nuclear test)">nuclear test of 1964</a>, as well as its repeated threats to intervene in support of Pakistan in the 1965 war, convinced India to develop nuclear weapons.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPerkovich200160–86,_106–125_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPerkovich200160–86,_106–125-273">[262]</a></sup> India conducted its <a href="/wiki/Smiling_Buddha" class="mw-redirect" title="Smiling Buddha">first nuclear weapons test</a> in 1974 and carried out <a href="/wiki/Pokhran-II" title="Pokhran-II">additional underground testing</a> in 1998. Despite criticism and military sanctions, India has signed neither the <a href="/wiki/Comprehensive_Nuclear-Test-Ban_Treaty" title="Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty">Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty</a> nor the <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_Non-Proliferation_Treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty">Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty</a>, considering both to be flawed and discriminatory.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKumar2010_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKumar2010-274">[263]</a></sup> India maintains a "<a href="/wiki/No_first_use" title="No first use">no first use</a>" nuclear policy and is developing a <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_triad" title="Nuclear triad">nuclear triad</a> capability as a part of its "<a href="/wiki/Minimum_Credible_Deterrence" class="mw-redirect" title="Minimum Credible Deterrence">Minimum Credible Deterrence</a>" doctrine.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENair2007_275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENair2007-275">[264]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPandit2009_276-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPandit2009-276">[265]</a></sup> It is developing a <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ballistic_Missile_Defense_Program" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian Ballistic Missile Defense Program">ballistic missile defence shield</a> and, a <a href="/wiki/HAL_AMCA" title="HAL AMCA">fifth-generation fighter jet</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Times_of_India_277-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Times_of_India-277">[266]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[267]</a></sup> Other indigenous military projects involve the design and implementation of <a href="/wiki/Vikrant_class_aircraft_carrier" class="mw-redirect" title="Vikrant class aircraft carrier"><i>Vikrant</i>-class aircraft carriers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arihant_class_submarine" class="mw-redirect" title="Arihant class submarine"><i>Arihant</i>-class nuclear submarines</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Hindu_2011_279-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hindu_2011-279">[268]</a></sup> </p>
