      <p>Since the end of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>, India has increased its economic, strategic, and military co-operation with the <a href="/wiki/India%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="India–United States relations">United States</a> and the <a href="/wiki/India%E2%80%93European_Union_relations" title="India–European Union relations">European Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEuropa_2008_280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEuropa_2008-280">[269]</a></sup> In 2008, a <a href="/wiki/U.S.%E2%80%93India_Civil_Nuclear_Agreement" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S.–India Civil Nuclear Agreement">civilian nuclear agreement</a> was signed between India and the United States. Although India possessed nuclear weapons at the time and was not a party to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, it received waivers from the <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">International Atomic Energy Agency</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_Suppliers_Group" title="Nuclear Suppliers Group">Nuclear Suppliers Group</a>, ending earlier restrictions on India's nuclear technology and commerce. As a consequence, India became the sixth de facto nuclear weapons state.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Times_of_India_2008_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Times_of_India_2008-281">[270]</a></sup> India subsequently signed co-operation agreements involving <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_India" title="Nuclear power in India">civilian nuclear energy</a> with Russia,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBritish_Broadcasting_Corporation_2009_282-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBritish_Broadcasting_Corporation_2009-282">[271]</a></sup> France,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERediff_2008_a_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERediff_2008_a-283">[272]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/India%E2%80%93United_Kingdom_relations" title="India–United Kingdom relations">United Kingdom</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReuters2010_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReuters2010-284">[273]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93India_relations" title="Canada–India relations">Canada</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECurry2010_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurry2010-285">[274]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:137px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Modi_Nieto_Mexico_June_2016.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Modi_Nieto_Mexico_June_2016.jpg/208px-Modi_Nieto_Mexico_June_2016.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="137" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Modi_Nieto_Mexico_June_2016.jpg/312px-Modi_Nieto_Mexico_June_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Modi_Nieto_Mexico_June_2016.jpg/416px-Modi_Nieto_Mexico_June_2016.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1218" data-file-height="804"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Narendra_Modi" title="Narendra Modi">Narendra Modi</a> of India (left, background) in talks with President <a href="/wiki/Enrique_Pe%C3%B1a_Nieto" title="Enrique Peña Nieto">Enrique Peña Nieto</a> of Mexico during a visit to Mexico, 2016
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The President of India is the supreme commander of the nation's armed forces; with 1.395&nbsp;million active troops, they compose the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_troops" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by number of troops">world's second-largest military</a>. It comprises the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Army" title="Indian Army">Indian Army</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Navy" title="Indian Navy">Indian Navy</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Air_Force" title="Indian Air Force">Indian Air Force</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Coast_Guard" title="Indian Coast Guard">Indian Coast Guard</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECentral_Intelligence_Agency_286-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECentral_Intelligence_Agency-286">[275]</a></sup> The official Indian <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">defence budget</a> for 2011 was US$36.03&nbsp;billion, or 1.83% of GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBehera2011_287-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBehera2011-287">[276]</a></sup> For the fiscal year spanning 2012–2013, US$40.44&nbsp;billion was budgeted.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBehera2012_288-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBehera2012-288">[277]</a></sup> According to a 2008 <a href="/wiki/Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute" title="Stockholm International Peace Research Institute">Stockholm International Peace Research Institute</a> (SIPRI) report, India's annual military expenditure in terms of purchasing power stood at US$72.7&nbsp;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute_2008178_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute_2008178-289">[278]</a></sup> In 2011, the annual defence budget increased by 11.6%,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiglani2011_290-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiglani2011-290">[279]</a></sup> although this does not include funds that reach the military through other branches of government.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShukla2011_291-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShukla2011-291">[280]</a></sup> As of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=India&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, India is the world's largest arms importer; between 2007 and 2011, it accounted for 10% of funds spent on international arms purchases.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStockholm_International_Peace_Research_Initiative_2012_292-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStockholm_International_Peace_Research_Initiative_2012-292">[281]</a></sup> Much of the military expenditure was focused on defence against Pakistan and countering growing Chinese influence in the Indian Ocean.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiglani2011_290-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiglani2011-290">[279]</a></sup> In May 2017, the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Space_Research_Organisation" title="Indian Space Research Organisation">Indian Space Research Organisation</a> launched the <a href="/wiki/South_Asia_Satellite" title="South Asia Satellite">South Asia Satellite</a>, a gift from India to its neighbouring <a href="/wiki/SAARC" class="mw-redirect" title="SAARC">SAARC</a> countries.<sup id="cite_ref-Deccan_Herald_293-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Deccan_Herald-293">[282]</a></sup> In October 2018, India signed a US$5.43&nbsp;billion (over <span style="white-space: nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Indian_rupee" title="Indian rupee">₹</a></span>400&nbsp;billion) agreement with <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> to procure four <a href="/wiki/S-400_Triumf" class="mw-redirect" title="S-400 Triumf">S-400 Triumf</a> surface-to-air missile defence systems, Russia's most advanced long-range <a href="/wiki/Missile_defence" class="mw-redirect" title="Missile defence">missile defence</a> system.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[283]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_India" title="Economy of India">Economy of India</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:432px;max-width:432px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:430px;max-width:430px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:285px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Plowing_the_land_in_India_-_modern_and_traditional.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Plowing_the_land_in_India_-_modern_and_traditional.jpg/428px-Plowing_the_land_in_India_-_modern_and_traditional.jpg" decoding="async" width="428" height="285" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Plowing_the_land_in_India_-_modern_and_traditional.jpg/642px-Plowing_the_land_in_India_-_modern_and_traditional.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Plowing_the_land_in_India_-_modern_and_traditional.jpg/856px-Plowing_the_land_in_India_-_modern_and_traditional.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4320" data-file-height="2880"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           A farmer in northwestern <a href="/wiki/Karnataka" title="Karnataka">Karnataka</a> ploughs his field with a tractor even as another in a field beyond does the same with a pair of oxen. In 2018, 44% of India's total workforce was employed in agriculture.<sup id="cite_ref-worldbank-ilo-total-agriculture_295-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank-ilo-total-agriculture-295">[284]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:196px;max-width:196px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:129px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:ILRI,_Stevie_Mann_-_Villager_and_calf_share_milk_from_cow_in_Rajasthan,_India.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/ILRI%2C_Stevie_Mann_-_Villager_and_calf_share_milk_from_cow_in_Rajasthan%2C_India.jpg/194px-ILRI%2C_Stevie_Mann_-_Villager_and_calf_share_milk_from_cow_in_Rajasthan%2C_India.jpg" decoding="async" width="194" height="129" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/ILRI%2C_Stevie_Mann_-_Villager_and_calf_share_milk_from_cow_in_Rajasthan%2C_India.jpg/291px-ILRI%2C_Stevie_Mann_-_Villager_and_calf_share_milk_from_cow_in_Rajasthan%2C_India.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/ILRI%2C_Stevie_Mann_-_Villager_and_calf_share_milk_from_cow_in_Rajasthan%2C_India.jpg/388px-ILRI%2C_Stevie_Mann_-_Villager_and_calf_share_milk_from_cow_in_Rajasthan%2C_India.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4368" data-file-height="2912"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           India is the world's largest producer of milk, with the largest population of cattle. In 2018, nearly 80% of India's milk was sourced from small farms with herd size between one and two, the milk harvested by hand milking.<sup id="cite_ref-milk-sourcing_297-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milk-sourcing-297">[286]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:232px;max-width:232px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:129px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Women_at_work,_Gujarat_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Women_at_work%2C_Gujarat_%28cropped%29.jpg/230px-Women_at_work%2C_Gujarat_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="230" height="129" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Women_at_work%2C_Gujarat_%28cropped%29.jpg/345px-Women_at_work%2C_Gujarat_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Women_at_work%2C_Gujarat_%28cropped%29.jpg/460px-Women_at_work%2C_Gujarat_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4995" data-file-height="2806"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Women tend to a recently planted rice field in <a href="/wiki/Junagadh" title="Junagadh">Junagadh</a> district in Gujarat. 57% of India's female workforce was employed in agriculture in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-worldbank-ilo-female-agriculture_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank-ilo-female-agriculture-296">[285]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> (IMF), the Indian economy in 2019 was nominally worth $2.9&nbsp;trillion; it is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">fifth-largest economy</a> by market exchange rates, and is around $11&nbsp;trillion, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">third-largest</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> (PPP).<sup id="cite_ref-imf2_23-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-23">[19]</a></sup> With its average annual GDP growth rate of 5.8% over the past two decades, and reaching 6.1% during 2011–2012,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund_2011a2_298-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund_2011a2-298">[287]</a></sup> India is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_real_GDP_growth_rate" title="List of countries by real GDP growth rate">world's fastest-growing economies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENayakGoldarAgrawal2010xxv_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENayakGoldarAgrawal2010xxv-299">[288]</a></sup> However, the country ranks 139th in the world in <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">nominal GDP per capita</a> and 118th in <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">GDP per capita at PPP</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund_300-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund-300">[289]</a></sup> Until 1991, all Indian governments followed <a href="/wiki/Protectionism" title="Protectionism">protectionist</a> policies that were influenced by socialist economics. Widespread <a href="/wiki/Licence_Raj" title="Licence Raj">state intervention and regulation</a> largely walled the economy off from the outside world. An acute <a href="/wiki/1991_India_economic_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="1991 India economic crisis">balance of payments crisis in 1991</a> forced the nation to <a href="/wiki/Economic_liberalisation_in_India" title="Economic liberalisation in India">liberalise its economy</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWolpert2003xiv_301-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWolpert2003xiv-301">[290]</a></sup> since then it has moved slowly towards a free-market system<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOrganisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development_2007_302-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOrganisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development_2007-302">[291]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGargan1992_303-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGargan1992-303">[292]</a></sup> by emphasising both foreign trade and direct investment inflows.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlamgir200823,_97_304-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlamgir200823,_97-304">[293]</a></sup> India has been a member of <a href="/wiki/WTO" class="mw-redirect" title="WTO">WTO</a> since 1 January 1995.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWTO_1995_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWTO_1995-305">[294]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The 513.7-million-worker <a href="/wiki/Labour_in_India" title="Labour in India">Indian labour force</a> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_labour_force" title="List of countries by labour force">world's second-largest</a>, as of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=India&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECentral_Intelligence_Agency_286-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECentral_Intelligence_Agency-286">[275]</a></sup> The service sector makes up 55.6% of GDP, the industrial sector 26.3% and the agricultural sector 18.1%. India's foreign exchange remittances of US$70&nbsp;billion in 2014, the largest in the world, were contributed to its economy by 25 million Indians working in foreign countries.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[295]</a></sup> Major agricultural products include: rice, wheat, oilseed, cotton, jute, tea, sugarcane, and potatoes.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress2004_260-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress2004-260">[249]</a></sup> Major industries include: textiles, telecommunications, chemicals, pharmaceuticals, biotechnology, food processing, steel, transport equipment, cement, mining, petroleum, machinery, and software.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress2004_260-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress2004-260">[249]</a></sup> In 2006, the share of external trade in India's GDP stood at 24%, up from 6% in 1985.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOrganisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development_2007_302-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOrganisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development_2007-302">[291]</a></sup> In 2008, India's share of world trade was 1.68%;<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[296]</a></sup> In 2011, India was the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_imports" title="List of countries by imports">tenth-largest importer</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports" title="List of countries by exports">nineteenth-largest exporter</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWorld_Trade_Organization_2010_308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWorld_Trade_Organization_2010-308">[297]</a></sup> Major exports include: petroleum products, textile goods, jewellery, software, engineering goods, chemicals, and manufactured leather goods.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress2004_260-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress2004-260">[249]</a></sup> Major imports include: crude oil, machinery, gems, fertiliser, and chemicals.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress2004_260-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress2004-260">[249]</a></sup> Between 2001 and 2011, the contribution of petrochemical and engineering goods to total exports grew from 14% to 42%.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEconomist_2011_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEconomist_2011-309">[298]</a></sup> India was the world's second largest textile exporter after <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> in the 2013 calendar year.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[299]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Averaging an economic growth rate of 7.5% for several years prior to 2007,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOrganisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development_2007_302-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOrganisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development_2007-302">[291]</a></sup> India has more than doubled its hourly wage rates during the first decade of the 21st century.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBonner2010_311-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBonner2010-311">[300]</a></sup> Some 431 million Indians have left poverty since 1985; India's middle classes are projected to number around 580&nbsp;million by 2030.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFarrellBeinhocker2007_312-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFarrellBeinhocker2007-312">[301]</a></sup> Though ranking 51st in <a href="/wiki/Global_Competitiveness_Report" title="Global Competitiveness Report">global competitiveness</a>, as of 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=India&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, India ranks 17th in financial market sophistication, 24th in the banking sector, 44th in business sophistication, and 39th in innovation, ahead of several advanced economies.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchwab2010_313-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchwab2010-313">[302]</a></sup> With seven of the world's top 15 information technology outsourcing companies based in India, as of 2009<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=India&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the country is viewed as the second-most favourable outsourcing destination after the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESheth2009_314-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESheth2009-314">[303]</a></sup> India's consumer market, the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_consumer_markets" title="List of largest consumer markets">eleventh-largest</a>, is expected to become fifth-largest by 2030.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFarrellBeinhocker2007_312-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFarrellBeinhocker2007-312">[301]</a></sup> Increasing access to electricity and <a href="/wiki/Clean_cooking" class="mw-redirect" title="Clean cooking">clean cooking</a> have been the priorities for <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_India" title="Energy in India">energy in India</a>:<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">[304]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Coal_in_India" title="Coal in India">the country's coal</a> is a major cause of <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas_emissions_by_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Greenhouse gas emissions by India">greenhouse gas emissions by India</a> but <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_India" title="Renewable energy in India">the country's renewable energy</a> is competing strongly.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[305]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Driven by growth, India's nominal <a href="/wiki/GDP_per_capita" class="mw-redirect" title="GDP per capita">GDP per capita</a> increased steadily from US$329 in 1991, when economic liberalisation began, to US$1,265 in 2010, to an estimated US$1,723 in 2016. It is expected to grow to US$2,358 by 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-imf2_23-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-23">[19]</a></sup> However, it has remained lower than those of other Asian developing countries like Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Sri Lanka, and Thailand, and is expected to remain so in the near future. Its GDP per capita is higher than Pakistan, Nepal, Afghanistan and others.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund_2011b_317-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund_2011b-317">[306]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:492px;max-width:492px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:490px;max-width:490px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:110px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Bangalore_Panorama_edit1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Bangalore_Panorama_edit1.jpg/488px-Bangalore_Panorama_edit1.jpg" decoding="async" width="488" height="111" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Bangalore_Panorama_edit1.jpg/732px-Bangalore_Panorama_edit1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Bangalore_Panorama_edit1.jpg/976px-Bangalore_Panorama_edit1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="7715" data-file-height="1754"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           A panorama of <a href="/wiki/Bangalore" title="Bangalore">Bangalore</a>, the centre of India's software development economy. In the 1980s, when the first <a href="/wiki/Multinational_corporation" title="Multinational corporation">multinational corporations</a> began to set up centres in India, they chose Bangalore because of the large pool of skilled graduates in the area, in turn due to the many science and engineering colleges in the surrounding region.<sup id="cite_ref-ScottGarofoli2007_318-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ScottGarofoli2007-318">[307]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to a 2011 <a href="/wiki/PricewaterhouseCoopers" title="PricewaterhouseCoopers">PricewaterhouseCoopers</a> (PwC) report, India's GDP at purchasing power parity could overtake that of the United States by 2045.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHawksworthTiwari2011_319-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHawksworthTiwari2011-319">[308]</a></sup> During the next four decades, Indian GDP is expected to grow at an annualised average of 8%, making it potentially the world's fastest-growing major economy until 2050.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHawksworthTiwari2011_319-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHawksworthTiwari2011-319">[308]</a></sup> The report highlights key growth factors: a young and rapidly growing working-age population; growth in the manufacturing sector because of rising education and engineering skill levels; and sustained growth of the consumer market driven by a rapidly growing middle-class.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHawksworthTiwari2011_319-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHawksworthTiwari2011-319">[308]</a></sup> The World Bank cautions that, for India to achieve its economic potential, it must continue to focus on public sector reform, <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_India" title="Transport in India">transport infrastructure</a>, agricultural and rural development, removal of labour regulations, <a href="/wiki/Education_in_India" title="Education in India">education</a>, <a href="/wiki/Energy_policy_of_India" title="Energy policy of India">energy security</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_India" title="Healthcare in India">public health</a> and nutrition.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[309]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to the Worldwide Cost of Living Report 2017 released by the <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">Economist Intelligence Unit</a> (EIU) which was created by comparing more than 400 individual prices across 160 products and services, four of the cheapest cities were in India: <a href="/wiki/Bangalore" title="Bangalore">Bangalore</a> (3rd), <a href="/wiki/Mumbai" title="Mumbai">Mumbai</a> (5th), <a href="/wiki/Chennai" title="Chennai">Chennai</a> (5th) and <a href="/wiki/New_Delhi" title="New Delhi">New Delhi</a> (8th).<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[310]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Industries">Industries</span></h3> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:129px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Cherry_Resort_inside_Temi_Tea_Garden,_Namchi,_Sikkim.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Cherry_Resort_inside_Temi_Tea_Garden%2C_Namchi%2C_Sikkim.jpg/208px-Cherry_Resort_inside_Temi_Tea_Garden%2C_Namchi%2C_Sikkim.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="129" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Cherry_Resort_inside_Temi_Tea_Garden%2C_Namchi%2C_Sikkim.jpg/312px-Cherry_Resort_inside_Temi_Tea_Garden%2C_Namchi%2C_Sikkim.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Cherry_Resort_inside_Temi_Tea_Garden%2C_Namchi%2C_Sikkim.jpg/416px-Cherry_Resort_inside_Temi_Tea_Garden%2C_Namchi%2C_Sikkim.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4520" data-file-height="2804"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           A tea garden in Sikkim. India, the world's second largest-producer of tea, is a nation of one billion tea drinkers, who consume 70% of India's tea output.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>India's <a href="/wiki/Communications_in_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Communications in India">telecommunication industry</a> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_mobile_network_operators" title="List of mobile network operators">second-largest in the world</a> with over 1.2 billion subscribers. It contributes 6.5% to India's GDP. <sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[311]</a></sup> After the third quarter of 2017, India surpassed the US to become the second largest smartphone market in the world after China.<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">[312]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_India" title="Automotive industry in India">Indian automotive industry</a>, the world's second-fastest growing, increased domestic sales by 26% during 2009–2010,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBusiness_Line_2010_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBusiness_Line_2010-324">[313]</a></sup> and exports by 36% during 2008–2009.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEExpress_India_2009_325-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEExpress_India_2009-325">[314]</a></sup> India's capacity to generate electrical power is 300 gigawatts, of which 42 gigawatts is <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_India" title="Renewable energy in India">renewable</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Par_326-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Par-326">[315]</a></sup> At the end of 2011, the <a href="/wiki/Information_technology_in_India" title="Information technology in India">Indian IT industry</a> employed 2.8&nbsp;million professionals, generated revenues close to US$100&nbsp;billion equalling 7.5% of Indian GDP, and contributed 26% of India's merchandise exports.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENasscom_2011–2012_327-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENasscom_2011–2012-327">[316]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Pharmaceutical_industry_in_India" title="Pharmaceutical industry in India">pharmaceutical industry in India</a> is among the significant emerging markets for the global pharmaceutical industry. The Indian pharmaceutical market is expected to reach $48.5&nbsp;billion by 2020. India's R &amp; D spending constitutes 60% of the <a href="/wiki/Biopharmaceutical" title="Biopharmaceutical">biopharmaceutical</a> industry.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[317]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">[318]</a></sup> India is among the top 12 biotech destinations in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">[319]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYep2011_331-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYep2011-331">[320]</a></sup> The Indian biotech industry grew by 15.1% in 2012–2013, increasing its revenues from <span style="white-space: nowrap">₹</span>204.4&nbsp;billion (<a href="/wiki/Indian_rupee" title="Indian rupee">Indian rupees</a>) to <span style="white-space: nowrap">₹</span>235.24&nbsp;billion (US$3.94 billion at June 2013 exchange rates).<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[321]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Socio-economic_challenges">Socio-economic challenges</span></h3> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:156px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Female_health_workers_in_India_(34332433890).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Female_health_workers_in_India_%2834332433890%29.jpg/208px-Female_health_workers_in_India_%2834332433890%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="156" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Female_health_workers_in_India_%2834332433890%29.jpg/312px-Female_health_workers_in_India_%2834332433890%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Female_health_workers_in_India_%2834332433890%29.jpg/416px-Female_health_workers_in_India_%2834332433890%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="960"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Health workers about to begin another day of immunisation against infectious diseases in 2006. Eight years later, and three years after India's last case of polio, the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> declared India to be polio-free.<sup id="cite_ref-who-chan-14-feb-2014_333-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-who-chan-14-feb-2014-333">[322]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Despite economic growth during recent decades, India continues to face socio-economic challenges. In 2006, India contained the <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_India" title="Poverty in India">largest number</a> of people living below the World Bank's international poverty line of US$1.25 per day.<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[323]</a></sup> The proportion decreased from 60% in 1981 to 42% in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[324]</a></sup> Under the World Bank's later revised poverty line, it was 21% in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[l]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-WB2015_338-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WB2015-338">[326]</a></sup> 30.7% of India's children under the age of five are underweight.<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[327]</a></sup> According to a <a href="/wiki/Food_and_Agriculture_Organization" title="Food and Agriculture Organization">Food and Agriculture Organization</a> report in 2015, 15% of the population is undernourished.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[328]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[329]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Mid-Day_Meal_Scheme" class="mw-redirect" title="Mid-Day Meal Scheme">Mid-Day Meal Scheme</a> attempts to lower these rates.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDrèzeGoyal200846_342-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDrèzeGoyal200846-342">[330]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to a 2016 <a href="/wiki/Walk_Free_Foundation" class="mw-redirect" title="Walk Free Foundation">Walk Free Foundation</a> report there were an estimated 18.3&nbsp;million people in India, or 1.4% of the population, living in the forms of <a href="/wiki/Modern_slavery" class="mw-redirect" title="Modern slavery">modern slavery</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Bonded_labour" class="mw-redirect" title="Bonded labour">bonded labour</a>, <a href="/wiki/Child_labour" title="Child labour">child labour</a>, human trafficking, and forced begging, among others.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[331]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">[332]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">[333]</a></sup> According to the 2011 census, there were 10.1&nbsp;million child labourers in the country, a decline of 2.6&nbsp;million from 12.6&nbsp;million in 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">[334]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since 1991, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Indian_states_by_GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Indian states by GDP">economic inequality</a> between India's states has consistently grown: the per-capita <a href="/wiki/Net_domestic_product" title="Net domestic product">net state domestic product</a> of the richest states in 2007 was 3.2 times that of the poorest.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalGhosh2007_347-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalGhosh2007-347">[335]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_India" title="Corruption in India">Corruption in India</a> is perceived to have decreased. According to the <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a>, India ranked 78th out of 180 countries in 2018 with a score of 41 out of 100, an improvement from 85th in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">[336]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[337]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span id="Demographics.2C_languages.2C_and_religion"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics,_languages,_and_religion">Demographics, languages, and religion</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_India" title="Demographics of India">Demographics of India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_India" title="Languages of India">Languages of India</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_India" title="Religion in India">Religion in India</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:432px;max-width:432px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="theader">
          India by population density, religion, language
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:247px;max-width:247px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:196px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:India_Population_Density_1909.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/India_Population_Density_1909.jpg/245px-India_Population_Density_1909.jpg" decoding="async" width="245" height="197" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/India_Population_Density_1909.jpg/368px-India_Population_Density_1909.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/India_Population_Density_1909.jpg/490px-India_Population_Density_1909.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6038" data-file-height="4844"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The population density of India by natural divisions, based on the Indian census of 1901
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:181px;max-width:181px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:196px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:2011_Census_India_population_density_map,_states_and_union_territories.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/2011_Census_India_population_density_map%2C_states_and_union_territories.svg/179px-2011_Census_India_population_density_map%2C_states_and_union_territories.svg.png" decoding="async" width="179" height="197" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/2011_Census_India_population_density_map%2C_states_and_union_territories.svg/269px-2011_Census_India_population_density_map%2C_states_and_union_territories.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/2011_Census_India_population_density_map%2C_states_and_union_territories.svg/358px-2011_Census_India_population_density_map%2C_states_and_union_territories.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1578" data-file-height="1738"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Population density of India by each state, based on the Indian census of 2011
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:255px;max-width:255px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:204px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Brit_IndianEmpireReligions3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Brit_IndianEmpireReligions3.jpg/253px-Brit_IndianEmpireReligions3.jpg" decoding="async" width="253" height="205" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Brit_IndianEmpireReligions3.jpg/380px-Brit_IndianEmpireReligions3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Brit_IndianEmpireReligions3.jpg/506px-Brit_IndianEmpireReligions3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1534" data-file-height="1241"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The prevailing religions of South Asia based on district-wise majorities in the 1901 census
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:173px;max-width:173px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:204px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:South_Asian_Language_Families.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/South_Asian_Language_Families.png/171px-South_Asian_Language_Families.png" decoding="async" width="171" height="205" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/South_Asian_Language_Families.png/257px-South_Asian_Language_Families.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/South_Asian_Language_Families.png/342px-South_Asian_Language_Families.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="1201"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The language families of South Asia
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>With 1,210,193,422 residents reported in the <a href="/wiki/2011_Census_of_India" title="2011 Census of India">2011 provisional census report</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India160_350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India160-350">[338]</a></sup> India is the world's second-most populous country. Its population grew by 17.64% from 2001 to 2011,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India165_351-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India165-351">[339]</a></sup> compared to 21.54% growth in the previous decade (1991–2001).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India165_351-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India165-351">[339]</a></sup> The human sex ratio, according to the 2011 census, is 940 females per 1,000 males.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India160_350-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India160-350">[338]</a></sup> The median age was 27.6 as of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=India&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECentral_Intelligence_Agency_286-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECentral_Intelligence_Agency-286">[275]</a></sup> The first post-colonial census, conducted in 1951, counted 361&nbsp;million people.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[340]</a></sup> Medical advances made in the last 50 years as well as increased agricultural productivity brought about by the "<a href="/wiki/Green_Revolution_in_India" title="Green Revolution in India">Green Revolution</a>" have caused India's population to grow rapidly.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERorabacher201035–39_353-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERorabacher201035–39-353">[341]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The average life expectancy in India is at 68 years—69.6 years for women, 67.3 years for men.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[342]</a></sup> There are around 50 physicians per 100,000 Indians.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDevRao2009329_355-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDevRao2009329-355">[343]</a></sup> Migration from rural to urban areas has been an important dynamic in India's recent history. The number of people living in urban areas grew by 31.2% between 1991 and 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGarg2005_356-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGarg2005-356">[344]</a></sup> Yet, in 2001, over 70% still lived in rural areas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDysonVisaria2005115–129_357-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDysonVisaria2005115–129-357">[345]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERatna2007271–272_358-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERatna2007271–272-358">[346]</a></sup> The level of urbanisation increased further from 27.81% in the 2001 Census to 31.16% in the 2011 Census. The slowing down of the overall population growth rate was due to the sharp decline in the growth rate in rural areas since 1991.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChandramouli2011_359-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChandramouli2011-359">[347]</a></sup> According to the 2011 census, there are 53 <a href="/wiki/List_of_million-plus_urban_agglomerations_in_India" title="List of million-plus urban agglomerations in India">million-plus urban agglomerations in India</a>; among them <a href="/wiki/Mumbai" title="Mumbai">Mumbai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Delhi" title="Delhi">Delhi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kolkata" title="Kolkata">Kolkata</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chennai" title="Chennai">Chennai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bangalore" title="Bangalore">Bangalore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hyderabad" title="Hyderabad">Hyderabad</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ahmedabad" title="Ahmedabad">Ahmedabad</a>, in decreasing order by population.<sup id="cite_ref-censusindia_2011_360-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-censusindia_2011-360">[348]</a></sup> The literacy rate in 2011 was 74.04%: 65.46% among females and 82.14% among males.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India163_361-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India163-361">[349]</a></sup> The rural-urban literacy gap, which was 21.2 percentage points in 2001, dropped to 16.1 percentage points in 2011. The improvement in the rural literacy rate is twice that of urban areas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChandramouli2011_359-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChandramouli2011-359">[347]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kerala" title="Kerala">Kerala</a> is the most literate state with 93.91% literacy; while <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">Bihar</a> the least with 63.82%.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India163_361-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India163-361">[349]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:140px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Interior_of_San_Thome_Basilica.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Interior_of_San_Thome_Basilica.jpg/208px-Interior_of_San_Thome_Basilica.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="140" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Interior_of_San_Thome_Basilica.jpg/312px-Interior_of_San_Thome_Basilica.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Interior_of_San_Thome_Basilica.jpg/416px-Interior_of_San_Thome_Basilica.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4071" data-file-height="2744"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The interior of <a href="/wiki/San_Thome_Basilica" class="mw-redirect" title="San Thome Basilica">San Thome Basilica</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chennai" title="Chennai">Chennai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tamil_Nadu" title="Tamil Nadu">Tamil Nadu</a>. Christianity is believed to have been introduced to India by the late 2nd century by <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_India#Early_Christianity_in_India" title="Christianity in India">Syriac-speaking Christians</a>.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>India is home to <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_India" title="Languages of India">two major language families</a>: <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_languages" title="Indo-Aryan languages">Indo-Aryan</a> (spoken by about 74% of the population) and <a href="/wiki/Dravidian_languages" title="Dravidian languages">Dravidian</a> (spoken by 24% of the population). Other languages spoken in India come from the <a href="/wiki/Austroasiatic_languages" title="Austroasiatic languages">Austroasiatic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sino-Tibetan_languages" title="Sino-Tibetan languages">Sino-Tibetan</a> language families. India has no national language.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDharwadker2010168–194,_186_362-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDharwadker2010168–194,_186-362">[350]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a>, with the largest number of speakers, is the official language of the government.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOttenheimer2008303_363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOttenheimer2008303-363">[351]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMallikarjun2004_364-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMallikarjun2004-364">[352]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> is used extensively in business and administration and has the status of a "subsidiary official language";<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Home_Affairs_1960_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Home_Affairs_1960-6">[5]</a></sup> it is important in <a href="/wiki/Education_in_India" title="Education in India">education</a>, especially as a medium of higher education. Each state and union territory has one or more official languages, and the constitution recognises in particular 22 "scheduled languages". </p>
      <p>The 2011 census reported the <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_India" title="Religion in India">religion in India</a> with the largest number of followers was <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_India" title="Hinduism in India">Hinduism</a> (79.80% of the population), followed by <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_India" title="Islam in India">Islam</a> (14.23%); the remaining were <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_India" title="Christianity in India">Christianity</a> (2.30%), <a href="/wiki/Sikhism_in_India" title="Sikhism in India">Sikhism</a> (1.72%), <a href="/wiki/History_of_Buddhism_in_India" title="History of Buddhism in India">Buddhism</a> (0.70%), <a href="/wiki/Statistics_of_Jainism" class="mw-redirect" title="Statistics of Jainism">Jainism</a> (0.36%) and others<sup id="cite_ref-remaining_religions_365-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-remaining_religions-365">[m]</a></sup> (0.9%).<sup id="cite_ref-Census2011religion_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census2011religion-17">[14]</a></sup> India has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Muslim_population#List" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by Muslim population">third-largest</a> Muslim population—the largest for a non-Muslim majority country.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">[353]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">[354]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_India" title="Culture of India">Culture of India</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:138px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Sikh_pilgrim_at_the_Golden_Temple_(Harmandir_Sahib)_in_Amritsar,_India.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Sikh_pilgrim_at_the_Golden_Temple_%28Harmandir_Sahib%29_in_Amritsar%2C_India.jpg/208px-Sikh_pilgrim_at_the_Golden_Temple_%28Harmandir_Sahib%29_in_Amritsar%2C_India.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="138" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Sikh_pilgrim_at_the_Golden_Temple_%28Harmandir_Sahib%29_in_Amritsar%2C_India.jpg/312px-Sikh_pilgrim_at_the_Golden_Temple_%28Harmandir_Sahib%29_in_Amritsar%2C_India.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Sikh_pilgrim_at_the_Golden_Temple_%28Harmandir_Sahib%29_in_Amritsar%2C_India.jpg/416px-Sikh_pilgrim_at_the_Golden_Temple_%28Harmandir_Sahib%29_in_Amritsar%2C_India.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3008" data-file-height="2000"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           A Sikh pilgrim at the <a href="/wiki/Harmandir_Sahib" class="mw-redirect" title="Harmandir Sahib">Harmandir Sahib</a>, or Golden Temple, in <a href="/wiki/Amritsar" title="Amritsar">Amritsar</a>, Punjab
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Indian cultural history spans more than <span class="nowrap">4,500 years</span>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKuiper201015_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKuiper201015-368">[355]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Vedic_period" title="Vedic period">Vedic period</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1700&nbsp;BCE</span>&nbsp;– c.<span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 500&nbsp;BCE</span>), the foundations of <a href="/wiki/Hindu_philosophy" title="Hindu philosophy">Hindu philosophy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_mythology" title="Hindu mythology">mythology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_theology" class="mw-redirect" title="Hindu theology">theology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hindu_texts" title="Hindu texts">literature</a> were laid, and many beliefs and practices which still exist today, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">dhárma</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">kárma</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">yóga</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">mokṣa</a></i>, were established.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKuiper201086_71-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKuiper201086-71">[63]</a></sup> India is notable for its <a href="/wiki/Indian_religions" title="Indian religions">religious diversity</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikhism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a> among the nation's major religions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHeehs20022–5_369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeehs20022–5-369">[356]</a></sup> The predominant religion, Hinduism, has been shaped by various historical schools of thought, including those of the <i><a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutsch19693,_78_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutsch19693,_78-370">[357]</a></sup> the <i><a href="/wiki/Yoga_Sutras_of_Patanjali" title="Yoga Sutras of Patanjali">Yoga Sutras</a></i>, the <a href="/wiki/Bhakti" title="Bhakti"><i>Bhakti</i> movement</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHeehs20022–5_369-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeehs20022–5-369">[356]</a></sup> and by <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_philosophy" title="Buddhist philosophy">Buddhist philosophy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENakamura1999_371-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENakamura1999-371">[358]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_art">Visual art</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Shiva_as_Lord_of_the_Dance_(Nataraja).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Shiva_as_Lord_of_the_Dance_%28Nataraja%29.jpg/220px-Shiva_as_Lord_of_the_Dance_%28Nataraja%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="247" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Shiva_as_Lord_of_the_Dance_%28Nataraja%29.jpg/330px-Shiva_as_Lord_of_the_Dance_%28Nataraja%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Shiva_as_Lord_of_the_Dance_%28Nataraja%29.jpg/440px-Shiva_as_Lord_of_the_Dance_%28Nataraja%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2008" data-file-height="2250"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Shiva_as_Lord_of_the_Dance_(Nataraja).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Chola_bronze" class="mw-redirect" title="Chola bronze">Chola bronze</a> of <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a> as <a href="/wiki/Nataraja" title="Nataraja">Nataraja</a> ("Lord of Dance"), <a href="/wiki/Tamil_Nadu" title="Tamil Nadu">Tamil Nadu</a>, 10th or 11th century.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Indian_art" title="Indian art">Indian art</a>
      </div> 
      <p>South Asia has an ancient tradition of art, which has exchanged influences with the parts of <a href="/wiki/Eurasia" title="Eurasia">Eurasia</a>. <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilisation#Seals" title="Indus Valley Civilisation">Seals</a> from the third millennium BCE <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Indus Valley Civilization">Indus Valley Civilization</a> of <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> and northern India have been found, usually carved with animals, but a few with human figures. The <a href="/wiki/%22Pashupati%22_seal" class="mw-redirect" title="&quot;Pashupati&quot; seal">"Pashupati" seal</a>, excavated in <a href="/wiki/Mohenjo-daro" title="Mohenjo-daro">Mohenjo-daro</a>, Pakistan, in 1928–29, is the best known.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[359]</a></sup> After this there is a long period with virtually nothing surviving.<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[360]</a></sup> Almost all surviving ancient Indian art thereafter is in various forms of religious <a href="/wiki/Indian_sculpture" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian sculpture">sculpture</a> in durable materials, or coins. There was probably originally far more in wood, which is lost. In north India <a href="/wiki/Mauryan_art" title="Mauryan art">Mauryan art</a> is the first imperial movement.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[361]</a></sup> In the first millennium CE, <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_art" title="Buddhist art">Buddhist art</a> spread with Indian religions to <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East</a> and <a href="/wiki/South-East_Asia" class="mw-redirect" title="South-East Asia">South-East Asia</a>, the last also greatly influenced by Hindu art.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[362]</a></sup> Over the following centuries a distinctly Indian style of sculpting the human figure developed, with less interest in articulating precise anatomy than <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_sculpture" title="Ancient Greek sculpture">ancient Greek sculpture</a> but showing smoothly-flowing forms expressing <i>prana</i> ("breath" or life-force).<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[363]</a></sup> This is often complicated by the need to give figures multiple arms or heads, or represent different genders on the left and right of figures, as with the <a href="/wiki/Ardhanarishvara" title="Ardhanarishvara">Ardhanarishvara</a> form of Shiva and <a href="/wiki/Parvati" title="Parvati">Parvati</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[364]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Most of the earliest large sculpture is Buddhist, either excavated from Buddhist <a href="/wiki/Stupa" title="Stupa">stupas</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Sanchi" title="Sanchi">Sanchi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sarnath" title="Sarnath">Sarnath</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amaravati_Stupa" title="Amaravati Stupa">Amaravati</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">[365]</a></sup> or is rock-cut <a href="/wiki/Relief" title="Relief">reliefs</a> at sites such as <a href="/wiki/Ajanta_Caves" title="Ajanta Caves">Ajanta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karla_Caves" title="Karla Caves">Karla</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ellora" class="mw-redirect" title="Ellora">Ellora</a>. Hindu and Jain sites appear rather later.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[366]</a></sup> In spite of this complex mixture of religious traditions, generally, the prevailing artistic style at any time and place has been shared by the major religious groups, and sculptors probably usually served all communities.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">[367]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gupta_art" title="Gupta art">Gupta art</a>, at its peak <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 300&nbsp;<span title="Common Era">CE</span></span>&nbsp;– c.<span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 500&nbsp;<span title="Common Era">CE</span></span>, is often regarded as a classical period whose influence lingered for many centuries after; it saw a new dominance of Hindu sculpture, as at the <a href="/wiki/Elephanta_Caves" title="Elephanta Caves">Elephanta Caves</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[368]</a></sup> Across the north, this became rather stiff and formulaic after <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 800&nbsp;<span title="Common Era">CE</span></span>, though rich with finely carved detail in the surrounds of statues.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[369]</a></sup> But in the South, under the <a href="/wiki/Pallava_dynasty" title="Pallava dynasty">Pallava</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chola_dynasty" title="Chola dynasty">Chola dynasties</a>, sculpture in both stone and bronze had a <a href="/wiki/Chola_art_and_architecture#Sculpture_and_bronzes" title="Chola art and architecture">sustained period of great achievement</a>; the large bronzes with Shiva as <a href="/wiki/Nataraja" title="Nataraja">Nataraja</a> have become an iconic symbol of India.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[370]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ancient painting has only survived at a few sites, of which the crowded scenes of court life in the <a href="/wiki/Ajanta_Caves" title="Ajanta Caves">Ajanta Caves</a> are by far the most important, but it was evidently highly developed, and is mentioned as a courtly accomplishment in Gupta times.<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[371]</a></sup> Painted manuscripts of religious texts survive from Eastern India about the 10th century onwards, most of the earliest being Buddhist and later Jain. No doubt the style of these was used in larger paintings.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[372]</a></sup> The Persian-derived <a href="/wiki/Deccan_painting" title="Deccan painting">Deccan painting</a>, starting just before the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_miniature" class="mw-redirect" title="Mughal miniature">Mughal miniature</a>, between them give the first large body of secular painting, with an emphasis on portraits, and the recording of princely pleasures and wars.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[373]</a></sup> The style spread to Hindu courts, especially <a href="/wiki/Rajput_painting" title="Rajput painting">among the Rajputs</a>, and developed a variety of styles, with the smaller courts often the most innovative, with figures such as <a href="/wiki/Nih%C3%A2l_Chand" title="Nihâl Chand">Nihâl Chand</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nainsukh" title="Nainsukh">Nainsukh</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[374]</a></sup> As a market developed among European residents, it was supplied by <a href="/wiki/Company_painting" class="mw-redirect" title="Company painting">Company painting</a> by Indian artists with considerable Western influence.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[375]</a></sup> In the 19th century, cheap <a href="/wiki/Kalighat_painting" title="Kalighat painting">Kalighat paintings</a> of gods and everyday life, done on paper, were urban <a href="/wiki/Folk_art" title="Folk art">folk art</a> from <a href="/wiki/Calcutta" class="mw-redirect" title="Calcutta">Calcutta</a>, which later saw the <a href="/wiki/Bengal_School_of_Art" title="Bengal School of Art">Bengal School of Art</a>, reflecting the art colleges founded by the British, the first movement in <a href="/wiki/Modern_Indian_painting" title="Modern Indian painting">modern Indian painting</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[376]</a></sup> </p> 
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed"> 
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 218px">
        <div style="width: 218px"> 
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 216px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Bhutesvara_Yakshis_Mathura_reliefs_2nd_century_CE_front.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Bhutesvara_Yakshis_Mathura_reliefs_2nd_century_CE_front.jpg/324px-Bhutesvara_Yakshis_Mathura_reliefs_2nd_century_CE_front.jpg" decoding="async" width="216" height="200" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Bhutesvara_Yakshis_Mathura_reliefs_2nd_century_CE_front.jpg/486px-Bhutesvara_Yakshis_Mathura_reliefs_2nd_century_CE_front.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Bhutesvara_Yakshis_Mathura_reliefs_2nd_century_CE_front.jpg/648px-Bhutesvara_Yakshis_Mathura_reliefs_2nd_century_CE_front.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2610" data-file-height="2418"></a>

         </div>
