      </ul> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture_and_literature">Architecture and literature</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_India" title="Architecture of India">Architecture of India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indian_literature" title="Indian literature">Indian literature</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;max-width:192px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:190px;max-width:190px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:289px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Gomateswara,_Shravanabelagola.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Gomateswara%2C_Shravanabelagola.jpg/188px-Gomateswara%2C_Shravanabelagola.jpg" decoding="async" width="188" height="290" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Gomateswara%2C_Shravanabelagola.jpg/282px-Gomateswara%2C_Shravanabelagola.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Gomateswara%2C_Shravanabelagola.jpg/376px-Gomateswara%2C_Shravanabelagola.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2733" data-file-height="4213"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           A Jain woman washes the feet of <a href="/wiki/Bahubali" title="Bahubali">Bahubali</a> Gomateswara at <a href="/wiki/Shravanabelagola" title="Shravanabelagola">Shravanabelagola</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karnataka" title="Karnataka">Karnataka</a>.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Much of <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_India" title="Architecture of India">Indian architecture</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Taj_Mahal" title="Taj Mahal">Taj Mahal</a>, other works of <a href="/wiki/Mughal_architecture" title="Mughal architecture">Mughal architecture</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Dravidian_architecture" title="Dravidian architecture">South Indian architecture</a>, blends ancient local traditions with imported styles.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKuiper2010296–329_390-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKuiper2010296–329-390">[377]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Indian_vernacular_architecture" title="Indian vernacular architecture">Vernacular architecture</a> is also regional in its flavours. <i><a href="/wiki/Vastu_shastra" title="Vastu shastra">Vastu shastra</a></i>, literally "science of construction" or "architecture" and ascribed to <a href="/wiki/Mamuni_Mayan" title="Mamuni Mayan">Mamuni Mayan</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESilverman200720_391-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESilverman200720-391">[378]</a></sup> explores how the laws of nature affect human dwellings;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKumar20005_392-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKumar20005-392">[379]</a></sup> it employs precise geometry and directional alignments to reflect perceived cosmic constructs.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts200473_393-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts200473-393">[380]</a></sup> As applied in <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple_architecture" title="Hindu temple architecture">Hindu temple architecture</a>, it is influenced by the <i><a href="/wiki/Shilpa_Shastras" title="Shilpa Shastras">Shilpa Shastras</a></i>, a series of foundational texts whose basic mythological form is the <i>Vastu-Purusha mandala</i>, a square that embodied the "<a href="/wiki/Absolute_(philosophy)" title="Absolute (philosophy)">absolute</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELangMoleski2010151–152_394-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELangMoleski2010151–152-394">[381]</a></sup> The Taj Mahal, built in <a href="/wiki/Agra" title="Agra">Agra</a> between 1631 and 1648 by orders of Emperor <a href="/wiki/Shah_Jahan" title="Shah Jahan">Shah Jahan</a> in memory of his wife, has been described in the <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_List" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO World Heritage List">UNESCO World Heritage List</a> as "the jewel of Muslim art in India and one of the universally admired masterpieces of the world's heritage".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations_Educational,_Scientific,_and_Cultural_Organisation_395-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations_Educational,_Scientific,_and_Cultural_Organisation-395">[382]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Indo-Saracenic_Revival_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Saracenic Revival architecture">Indo-Saracenic Revival architecture</a>, developed by the British in the late 19th century, drew on <a href="/wiki/Indo-Islamic_architecture" title="Indo-Islamic architecture">Indo-Islamic architecture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChopra201146_396-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChopra201146-396">[383]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The earliest literature in India, composed between 1500&nbsp;BCE and 1200&nbsp;<span title="Common Era">CE</span>, was in the <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> language.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoibergRamchandani2000_397-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoibergRamchandani2000-397">[384]</a></sup> Major works of <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit_literature" title="Sanskrit literature">Sanskrit literature</a> include the <i><a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a></i> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1500&nbsp;BCE</span>&nbsp;– c.<span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1200&nbsp;BCE</span>), the <a href="/wiki/Indian_epic_poetry" title="Indian epic poetry">epics</a>: <i><a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahābhārata</a></i> ( <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 400&nbsp;BCE</span>&nbsp;– c.<span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 400&nbsp;<span title="Common Era">CE</span></span>) and the <i><a href="/wiki/Ramayana" title="Ramayana">Ramayana</a></i> ( <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 300&nbsp;BCE</span> and later); <i>Abhijñānaśākuntalam</i> (<i><a href="/wiki/The_Recognition_of_%C5%9Aakuntal%C4%81" class="mw-redirect" title="The Recognition of Śakuntalā">The Recognition of Śakuntalā</a></i>, and other dramas of <a href="/wiki/K%C4%81lid%C4%81sa" class="mw-redirect" title="Kālidāsa">Kālidāsa</a> ( <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 5th century&nbsp;<span title="Common Era">CE</span></span>) and <i><a href="/wiki/Sanskrit_Classical_poetry" class="mw-redirect" title="Sanskrit Classical poetry">Mahākāvya</a></i> poetry.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJohnson2008_398-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJohnson2008-398">[385]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacDonell20041–40_399-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacDonell20041–40-399">[386]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKālidāsaJohnson2001_400-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKālidāsaJohnson2001-400">[387]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Tamil_literature" title="Tamil literature">Tamil literature</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sangam_literature" title="Sangam literature">Sangam literature</a> ( <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 600&nbsp;BCE</span>&nbsp;– c.<span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 300&nbsp;BCE</span>) consisting of 2,381 poems, composed by 473 poets, is the earliest work.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZvelebil199712_401-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZvelebil199712-401">[388]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHart1975_402-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHart1975-402">[389]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEncyclopædia_Britannica2008_403-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEncyclopædia_Britannica2008-403">[390]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERamanujan1985ix–x_404-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERamanujan1985ix–x-404">[391]</a></sup> From the 14th to the 18th centuries, India's literary traditions went through a period of drastic change because of the emergence of <a href="/wiki/Bhakti_movement" title="Bhakti movement">devotional poets</a> like <a href="/wiki/Kabir" title="Kabir">Kabīr</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tulsidas" title="Tulsidas">Tulsīdās</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Guru_Nanak" title="Guru Nanak">Guru Nānak</a>. This period was characterised by a varied and wide spectrum of thought and expression; as a consequence, medieval Indian literary works differed significantly from classical traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDas2005_405-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDas2005-405">[392]</a></sup> In the 19th century, Indian writers took a new interest in social questions and psychological descriptions. In the 20th century, Indian literature was influenced by the <a href="/wiki/Works_of_Rabindranath_Tagore" title="Works of Rabindranath Tagore">works</a> of the Bengali poet, author and philosopher <a href="/wiki/Rabindranath_Tagore" title="Rabindranath Tagore">Rabindranath Tagore</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDatta2006_406-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDatta2006-406">[393]</a></sup> who was a recipient of the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Performing_arts_and_media">Performing arts and media</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_India" title="Music of India">Music of India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dance_in_India" title="Dance in India">Dance in India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_India" title="Cinema of India">Cinema of India</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Television_in_India" title="Television in India">Television in India</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;max-width:192px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:190px;max-width:190px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:265px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Kuchipudi_Performer_DS.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Kuchipudi_Performer_DS.jpg/188px-Kuchipudi_Performer_DS.jpg" decoding="async" width="188" height="266" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Kuchipudi_Performer_DS.jpg/282px-Kuchipudi_Performer_DS.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Kuchipudi_Performer_DS.jpg/376px-Kuchipudi_Performer_DS.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1700" data-file-height="2405"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           India's <a href="/wiki/Sangeet_Natak_Akademi" title="Sangeet Natak Akademi">National Academy of Performance Arts</a> has recognised eight Indian dance styles to be <i>classical</i>. One such is <a href="/wiki/Kuchipudi" title="Kuchipudi">Kuchipudi</a> shown here.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Music_of_India" title="Music of India">Indian music</a> ranges over various traditions and regional styles. <a href="/wiki/Indian_classical_music" title="Indian classical music">Classical music</a> encompasses two genres and their various folk offshoots: the northern <a href="/wiki/Hindustani_classical_music" title="Hindustani classical music">Hindustani</a> and southern <a href="/wiki/Carnatic_music" title="Carnatic music">Carnatic</a> schools.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMasseyMassey1998_407-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMasseyMassey1998-407">[394]</a></sup> Regionalised popular forms include <a href="/wiki/Filmi" title="Filmi">filmi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indian_folk_music" title="Indian folk music">folk music</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Syncretism" title="Syncretism">syncretic</a> tradition of the <i><a href="/wiki/Baul" title="Baul">bauls</a></i> is a well-known form of the latter. <a href="/wiki/Dance_in_India" title="Dance in India">Indian dance</a> also features diverse folk and classical forms. Among the better-known <a href="/wiki/List_of_Indian_folk_dances" title="List of Indian folk dances">folk dances</a> are: the <i><a href="/wiki/Bhangra_(dance)" title="Bhangra (dance)">bhangra</a></i> of Punjab, the <i><a href="/wiki/Bihu_dance" title="Bihu dance">bihu</a></i> of Assam, the <i><a href="/wiki/Jhumair" title="Jhumair">Jhumair</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Chhau_dance" title="Chhau dance">chhau</a></i> of Jharkhand, Odisha and West Bengal, <i><a href="/wiki/Garba_(dance)" title="Garba (dance)">garba</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Dandiya_Raas" title="Dandiya Raas">dandiya</a></i> of Gujarat, <i><a href="/wiki/Ghoomar" title="Ghoomar">ghoomar</a></i> of Rajasthan, and the <i><a href="/wiki/Lavani" title="Lavani">lavani</a></i> of Maharashtra. Eight dance forms, many with narrative forms and mythological elements, have been accorded <a href="/wiki/Classical_Indian_dance" class="mw-redirect" title="Classical Indian dance">classical dance status</a> by India's <a href="/wiki/Sangeet_Natak_Akademi" title="Sangeet Natak Akademi">National Academy of Music, Dance, and Drama</a>. These are: <i><a href="/wiki/Bharata_Natyam" class="mw-redirect" title="Bharata Natyam">bharatanatyam</a></i> of the state of Tamil Nadu, <i><a href="/wiki/Kathak" title="Kathak">kathak</a></i> of Uttar Pradesh, <i><a href="/wiki/Kathakali" title="Kathakali">kathakali</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Mohiniyattam" title="Mohiniyattam">mohiniyattam</a></i> of Kerala, <i><a href="/wiki/Kuchipudi" title="Kuchipudi">kuchipudi</a></i> of Andhra Pradesh, <i><a href="/wiki/Manipuri_dance" title="Manipuri dance">manipuri</a></i> of Manipur, <i><a href="/wiki/Odissi" title="Odissi">odissi</a></i> of Odisha, and the <i><a href="/wiki/Sattriya" title="Sattriya">sattriya</a></i> of Assam.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEncyclopædia_Britannica_b_408-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEncyclopædia_Britannica_b-408">[395]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Theatre_in_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Theatre in India">Theatre in India</a> melds music, dance, and improvised or written dialogue.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELal200423,_30,_235_409-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELal200423,_30,_235-409">[396]</a></sup> Often based on Hindu mythology, but also borrowing from medieval romances or social and political events, Indian theatre includes: the <i><a href="/wiki/Bhavai" title="Bhavai">bhavai</a></i> of Gujarat, the <i><a href="/wiki/Jatra_(Bengal)" class="mw-redirect" title="Jatra (Bengal)">jatra</a></i> of West Bengal, the <i><a href="/wiki/Nautanki" title="Nautanki">nautanki</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Ramlila" title="Ramlila">ramlila</a></i> of North India, <i><a href="/wiki/Tamasha" title="Tamasha">tamasha</a></i> of Maharashtra, <i><a href="/wiki/Burrakatha" class="mw-redirect" title="Burrakatha">burrakatha</a></i> of Andhra Pradesh, <i><a href="/wiki/Terukkuttu" title="Terukkuttu">terukkuttu</a></i> of Tamil Nadu, and the <i><a href="/wiki/Yakshagana" title="Yakshagana">yakshagana</a></i> of Karnataka.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKaranth200226_410-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKaranth200226-410">[397]</a></sup> India has a theatre training institute the <a href="/wiki/National_School_of_Drama" title="National School of Drama">National School of Drama</a> (NSD) that is situated at <a href="/wiki/New_Delhi" title="New Delhi">New Delhi</a> It is an autonomous organisation under the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture_(India)" title="Ministry of Culture (India)">Ministry of Culture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India" title="Government of India">Government of India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">[398]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_India" title="Cinema of India">Indian film industry</a> produces the world's most-watched cinema.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDissanayakeGokulsing2004_412-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDissanayakeGokulsing2004-412">[399]</a></sup> Established regional cinematic traditions exist in the <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Assam" class="mw-redirect" title="Cinema of Assam">Assamese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_West_Bengal" title="Cinema of West Bengal">Bengali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bhojpuri_cinema" title="Bhojpuri cinema">Bhojpuri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bollywood" title="Bollywood">Hindi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Karnataka" class="mw-redirect" title="Cinema of Karnataka">Kannada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malayalam_cinema" title="Malayalam cinema">Malayalam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Punjab" class="mw-redirect" title="Cinema of Punjab">Punjabi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_cinema" title="Gujarati cinema">Gujarati</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marathi_cinema" title="Marathi cinema">Marathi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Odisha" title="Cinema of Odisha">Odia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tamil_cinema" title="Tamil cinema">Tamil</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Telugu_cinema" title="Telugu cinema">Telugu</a> languages.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERajadhyakshaWillemen1999652_413-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERajadhyakshaWillemen1999652-413">[400]</a></sup> The Hindi language film industry (<i>Bollywood</i>) is the largest sector representing 43% of box office revenue, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_South_India" title="Cinema of South India">South Indian</a> Telugu and Tamil film industries which represent 36% combined.<sup id="cite_ref-deloitte_414-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-deloitte-414">[401]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Television broadcasting began in India in 1959 as a state-run medium of communication and expanded slowly for more than two decades.<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[402]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKaminskyLong2011684–692_416-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKaminskyLong2011684–692-416">[403]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Doordarshan" title="Doordarshan">state monopoly</a> on television broadcast ended in the 1990s. Since then, satellite channels have increasingly shaped the popular culture of Indian society.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMehta20081–10_417-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMehta20081–10-417">[404]</a></sup> Today, television is the most penetrative media in India; industry estimates indicate that as of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=India&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> there are over 554 million TV consumers, 462&nbsp;million with satellite or cable connections compared to other forms of mass media such as the press (350&nbsp;million), radio (156&nbsp;million) or internet (37&nbsp;million).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMedia_Research_Users_Council_2012_418-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMedia_Research_Users_Council_2012-418">[405]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Society">Society</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_India" title="Culture of India">Culture of India</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:139px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Muslims_praying_in_mosque_in_Srinagar,_Kashmir.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Muslims_praying_in_mosque_in_Srinagar%2C_Kashmir.jpg/208px-Muslims_praying_in_mosque_in_Srinagar%2C_Kashmir.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="139" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Muslims_praying_in_mosque_in_Srinagar%2C_Kashmir.jpg/312px-Muslims_praying_in_mosque_in_Srinagar%2C_Kashmir.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Muslims_praying_in_mosque_in_Srinagar%2C_Kashmir.jpg/416px-Muslims_praying_in_mosque_in_Srinagar%2C_Kashmir.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="685"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Muslims offer <i><a href="/wiki/Salah" title="Salah">namaz</a></i> at a mosque in <a href="/wiki/Srinagar" title="Srinagar">Srinagar</a>, Jammu and Kashmir.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Traditional Indian society is sometimes defined by social hierarchy. The <a href="/wiki/Caste_system_in_India" title="Caste system in India">Indian caste system</a> embodies much of the social stratification and many of the social restrictions found in the Indian subcontinent. Social classes are defined by thousands of <a href="/wiki/Endogamous" class="mw-redirect" title="Endogamous">endogamous</a> hereditary groups, often termed as <i><a href="/wiki/J%C4%81ti" title="Jāti">jātis</a></i>, or "castes".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchwartzberg2011_419-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchwartzberg2011-419">[406]</a></sup> India declared <a href="/wiki/Untouchability" title="Untouchability">untouchability</a> to be illegal<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">[407]</a></sup> in 1947 and has since enacted other anti-discriminatory laws and social welfare initiatives. </p>
      <p>Family values are important in the Indian tradition, and multi-generational patriarchal joint families have been the norm in India, though nuclear families are becoming common in urban areas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMakar2007_421-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMakar2007-421">[408]</a></sup> An overwhelming majority of Indians, with their consent, have <a href="/wiki/Arranged_marriage_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Arranged marriage in the Indian subcontinent">their marriages arranged</a> by their parents or other family elders.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMedora2003_422-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMedora2003-422">[409]</a></sup> Marriage is thought to be for life,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMedora2003_422-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMedora2003-422">[409]</a></sup> and the divorce rate is extremely low,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJonesRamdas2005111_423-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJonesRamdas2005111-423">[410]</a></sup> with less than one in a thousand marriages ending in divorce.<sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">[411]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Child_marriage" title="Child marriage">Child marriages</a> are common, especially in rural areas; many women wed before reaching 18, which is their legal marriageable age.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECullen-Dupont200996_425-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECullen-Dupont200996-425">[412]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Female_infanticide_in_India" title="Female infanticide in India">Female infanticide in India</a>, and lately <a href="/wiki/Female_foeticide_in_India" title="Female foeticide in India">female foeticide</a>, have created skewed gender ratios; the number of <a href="/wiki/Missing_women" title="Missing women">missing women</a> in the country quadrupled from 15 million to 63 million in the 50-year period ending in 2014, faster than the population growth during the same period, and constituting 20 percent of India's female electorate.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Hindu_November_17_2019c_426-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Hindu_November_17_2019c-426">[413]</a></sup> Accord to an Indian government study, an additional 21 million girls are unwanted and do not receive adequate care.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Guardian_November_17_2019c_427-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Guardian_November_17_2019c-427">[414]</a></sup> Despite a government ban on sex-selective foeticide, the practice remains commonplace in India, the result of a preference for boys in a patriarchal society.<sup id="cite_ref-Foreign_Policy_November_17_2019c_428-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Foreign_Policy_November_17_2019c-428">[415]</a></sup> The payment of <a href="/wiki/Dowry_system_in_India" title="Dowry system in India">dowry</a>, although <a href="/wiki/Dowry_law_in_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Dowry law in India">illegal</a>, remains widespread across class lines.<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[416]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dowry_deaths" class="mw-redirect" title="Dowry deaths">Deaths resulting from dowry</a>, mostly from <a href="/wiki/Bride_burning" title="Bride burning">bride burning</a>, are on the rise, despite stringent anti-dowry laws.<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">[417]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Many <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_India" title="Public holidays in India">Indian festivals</a> are religious in origin. The best known include: <a href="/wiki/Diwali" title="Diwali">Diwali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ganesh_Chaturthi" title="Ganesh Chaturthi">Ganesh Chaturthi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thai_Pongal" class="mw-redirect" title="Thai Pongal">Thai Pongal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Holi" title="Holi">Holi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Durga_Puja" title="Durga Puja">Durga Puja</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eid_ul-Fitr" class="mw-redirect" title="Eid ul-Fitr">Eid ul-Fitr</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bakr-Id" class="mw-redirect" title="Bakr-Id">Bakr-Id</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christmas_worldwide#India" class="mw-redirect" title="Christmas worldwide">Christmas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vaisakhi" title="Vaisakhi">Vaisakhi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">[418]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">[419]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_India" title="Education in India">Education in India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Literacy_in_India" title="Literacy in India">Literacy in India</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_education_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="History of education in the Indian subcontinent">History of education in the Indian subcontinent</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In the 2011 census, about 73% of the population was literate, with 81% for men and 65% for women. This compares to 1981 when the respective rates were 41%, 53% and 29%. In 1951 the rates were 18%, 27% and 9%. In 1921 the rates 7%, 12% and 2%. In 1891 they were 5%, 9% and 1%,<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[420]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">[421]</a></sup> According to Latika Chaudhary, in 1911 there were under three primary schools for every ten villages. Statistically, more caste and religious diversity reduced private spending. Primary schools taught literacy, so local diversity limited its growth.<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">[422]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Education system of India is the world's second largest higher education System.<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">[423]</a></sup> India had over 900 universities, 40,000 colleges<sup id="cite_ref-highered1_437-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-highered1-437">[424]</a></sup> and 1.5 million schools.<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438">[425]</a></sup> In India's higher education system, a significant number of seats are reserved under <a href="/wiki/Reservation_in_India" title="Reservation in India">affirmative action</a> policies for the historically disadvantaged. In recent decades India's improved education system is often cited as one of the main contributors to its <a href="/wiki/Economic_development_in_India" title="Economic development in India">economic development</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Sify_439-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sify-439">[426]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">[427]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Clothing">Clothing</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Clothing_in_India" title="Clothing in India">Clothing in India</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:492px;max-width:492px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:329px;max-width:329px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:244px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:India_School.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/India_School.jpg/327px-India_School.jpg" decoding="async" width="327" height="245" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/India_School.jpg/491px-India_School.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/India_School.jpg/654px-India_School.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Women in <a href="/wiki/Sari" title="Sari">sari</a> at an adult literacy class in <a href="/wiki/Tamil_Nadu" title="Tamil Nadu">Tamil Nadu</a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:159px;max-width:159px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:244px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Water_pump,_Varanasi_(15563170660)_Cropped.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Water_pump%2C_Varanasi_%2815563170660%29_Cropped.jpg/157px-Water_pump%2C_Varanasi_%2815563170660%29_Cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="157" height="244" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Water_pump%2C_Varanasi_%2815563170660%29_Cropped.jpg/236px-Water_pump%2C_Varanasi_%2815563170660%29_Cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Water_pump%2C_Varanasi_%2815563170660%29_Cropped.jpg/314px-Water_pump%2C_Varanasi_%2815563170660%29_Cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1488" data-file-height="2314"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           A man in <a href="/wiki/Dhoti" title="Dhoti">dhoti</a>, wearing a woollen shawl in <a href="/wiki/Varanasi" title="Varanasi">Varanasi</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The most widely worn traditional dress in India, for both women and men, from ancient times until the advent of modern times, was draped.<sup id="cite_ref-Tarlo1996-26_441-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tarlo1996-26-441">[428]</a></sup> For women it eventually took the form of a <a href="/wiki/Sari" title="Sari">sari</a>, a single long piece of cloth, famously six yards long, and of width spanning the lower body.<sup id="cite_ref-Tarlo1996-26_441-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tarlo1996-26-441">[428]</a></sup> The sari is tied around the waist and knotted at one end, wrapped around the lower body, and then over the shoulder.<sup id="cite_ref-Tarlo1996-26_441-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tarlo1996-26-441">[428]</a></sup> In its more modern form, it has been used to cover the head, and sometimes the face, as a veil.<sup id="cite_ref-Tarlo1996-26_441-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tarlo1996-26-441">[428]</a></sup> It has been combined with an underskirt, or Indian <a href="/wiki/Petticoat#Asian_petticoats" title="Petticoat">petticoat</a>, and tucked in the waist band for more secure fastening, It is also commonly worn with an Indian <a href="/wiki/Blouse" title="Blouse">blouse</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Choli" title="Choli">choli</a>, which serves as the primary upper-body garment, the sari's end—passing over the shoulder—serving to obscure the upper body's contours and to cover the midriff.<sup id="cite_ref-Tarlo1996-26_441-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tarlo1996-26-441">[428]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>For men, a similar but shorter length of cloth, the <a href="/wiki/Dhoti" title="Dhoti">dhoti</a>, has served as a lower-body garment.<sup id="cite_ref-Tarlo1996-26-28_442-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tarlo1996-26-28-442">[429]</a></sup> It too is tied around the waist and wrapped.<sup id="cite_ref-Tarlo1996-26-28_442-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tarlo1996-26-28-442">[429]</a></sup> In south India, it is usually wrapped around the lower body, the upper end tucked in the waistband, the lower left free. In addition, in northern India, it is also wrapped once around each leg before being brought up through the legs to be tucked in at the back. Other forms of traditional apparel that involve no stitching or tailoring are the <a href="/wiki/Chador" title="Chador">chaddar</a> (a shawl worn by both sexes to cover the upper body during colder weather, or a large veil worn by women for framing the head, or covering it) and the <a href="/wiki/Pagri_(turban)" title="Pagri (turban)">pagri</a> (a <a href="/wiki/Turban" title="Turban">turban</a> or a scarf worn around the head as a part of a tradition, or to keep off the sun or the cold).<sup id="cite_ref-Tarlo1996-26-28_442-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tarlo1996-26-28-442">[429]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:432px;max-width:432px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:149px;max-width:149px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:184px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Strolling_Shoppers_in_Paltan_Bazaar.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Strolling_Shoppers_in_Paltan_Bazaar.jpg/147px-Strolling_Shoppers_in_Paltan_Bazaar.jpg" decoding="async" width="147" height="184" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Strolling_Shoppers_in_Paltan_Bazaar.jpg/221px-Strolling_Shoppers_in_Paltan_Bazaar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Strolling_Shoppers_in_Paltan_Bazaar.jpg/294px-Strolling_Shoppers_in_Paltan_Bazaar.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1456" data-file-height="1821"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Women (from left to right) in <a href="/wiki/Churidar" title="Churidar">churidars</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kameez" class="mw-redirect" title="Kameez">kameez</a> (with back to the camera), jeans and sweater, and pink <a href="/wiki/Shalwar_kameez" title="Shalwar kameez">Shalwar kameez</a>;
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:279px;max-width:279px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:184px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Girls_in_Kargil.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Girls_in_Kargil.jpg/277px-Girls_in_Kargil.jpg" decoding="async" width="277" height="185" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Girls_in_Kargil.jpg/416px-Girls_in_Kargil.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Girls_in_Kargil.jpg/554px-Girls_in_Kargil.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1080" data-file-height="720"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Girls in the <a href="/wiki/Kashmir" title="Kashmir">Kashmir</a> region in embroidered <a href="/wiki/Hijab" title="Hijab">hijab</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:430px;max-width:430px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:295px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Happy_Tailor_(5274603493).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Happy_Tailor_%285274603493%29.jpg/428px-Happy_Tailor_%285274603493%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="428" height="295" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Happy_Tailor_%285274603493%29.jpg/642px-Happy_Tailor_%285274603493%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Happy_Tailor_%285274603493%29.jpg/856px-Happy_Tailor_%285274603493%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3558" data-file-height="2456"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           A tailor in <a href="/wiki/Pagri_(turban)" title="Pagri (turban)">pagri</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kameez" class="mw-redirect" title="Kameez">kameez</a> working outside a fabric shop
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Until the beginning of the first millennium CE, the ordinary dress of people in India was entirely unstitched.<sup id="cite_ref-Rahman-Alkazi2002_443-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rahman-Alkazi2002-443">[430]</a></sup> The arrival of the <a href="/wiki/Kushans" class="mw-redirect" title="Kushans">Kushans</a> from <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 48&nbsp;<span title="Common Era">CE</span></span>, popularised cut and sewn garments in the style of Central Asian favoured by the elite in northern India.<sup id="cite_ref-Rahman-Alkazi2002_443-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rahman-Alkazi2002-443">[430]</a></sup> However, it was not until Muslim rule was established, first with the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_sultanate" class="mw-redirect" title="Delhi sultanate">Delhi sultanate</a> and then the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a>, that the range of stitched clothes in India grew and their use became significantly more widespread.<sup id="cite_ref-Rahman-Alkazi2002_443-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rahman-Alkazi2002-443">[430]</a></sup> Among the various garments gradually establishing themselves in northern India during medieval and early-modern times and now commonly worn are: the <a href="/wiki/Shalwar" class="mw-redirect" title="Shalwar">shalwars</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pyjama" class="mw-redirect" title="Pyjama">pyjamas</a> both forms of trousers, as well as the tunics <a href="/wiki/Kurta" title="Kurta">kurta</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kameez" class="mw-redirect" title="Kameez">kameez</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Rahman-Alkazi2002_443-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rahman-Alkazi2002-443">[430]</a></sup> In southern India, however, the traditional draped garments were to see much longer continuous use.<sup id="cite_ref-Rahman-Alkazi2002_443-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rahman-Alkazi2002-443">[430]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Shalwars are atypically wide at the waist but narrow to a cuffed bottom. They are held up by a drawstring or elastic belt, which causes them to become pleated around the waist.<sup id="cite_ref-StevensonWaite2011_444-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-StevensonWaite2011-444">[431]</a></sup> The pants can be wide and baggy, or they can be cut quite narrow, on the <a href="/wiki/Grain_(textile)#Bias" title="Grain (textile)">bias</a>, in which case they are called <a href="/wiki/Churidar" title="Churidar">churidars</a>. The kameez is a long shirt or tunic.<sup id="cite_ref-StevensonWaite2011-b_445-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-StevensonWaite2011-b-445">[432]</a></sup> The side seams are left open below the waist-line,<sup id="cite_ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446">[433]</a></sup>), which gives the wearer greater freedom of movement. The kameez is usually cut straight and flat; older kameez use traditional cuts; modern kameez are more likely to have European-inspired <a href="/wiki/Batwing_sleeves" class="mw-redirect" title="Batwing sleeves">set-in sleeves</a>. The kameez may have a European-style collar, a Mandarin-collar, or it may be collarless; in the latter case, its design as a women's garment is similar to a kurta.<sup id="cite_ref-StevensonWaite2011-kurta_447-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-StevensonWaite2011-kurta-447">[434]</a></sup> At first worn by Muslim women, the use of shalwar kameez gradually spread, making them a regional style,<sup id="cite_ref-Tarlo1996-a_448-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tarlo1996-a-448">[435]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Tarlo1996-b_449-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tarlo1996-b-449">[436]</a></sup> especially in the <a href="/wiki/Punjab" title="Punjab">Punjab</a> region.<sup id="cite_ref-Mooney2011_450-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mooney2011-450">[437]</a></sup> <sup id="cite_ref-Shome2014_451-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shome2014-451">[438]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A <a href="/wiki/Kurta" title="Kurta">kurta</a>, which traces its roots to <a href="/wiki/Central_Asian" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Asian">Central Asian</a> nomadic <a href="/wiki/Tunic" title="Tunic">tunics</a>, has evolved stylistically in India as a garment for everyday wear as well as for formal occasions.<sup id="cite_ref-Rahman-Alkazi2002_443-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rahman-Alkazi2002-443">[430]</a></sup> It is traditionally made of cotton or silk; it is worn plain or with embroidered decoration, such as <a href="/wiki/Chikan_(embroidery)" title="Chikan (embroidery)">chikan</a>; and it can be loose or tight in the torso, typically falling either just above or somewhere below the wearer's knees.<sup id="cite_ref-Shukla2015_452-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shukla2015-452">[439]</a></sup> The sleeves of a traditional kurta fall to the wrist without narrowing, the ends hemmed but not cuffed; the kurta can be worn by both men and women; it is traditionally collarless, though <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_collar" title="Mandarin collar">standing collars</a> are increasingly popular; and it can be worn over ordinary <a href="/wiki/Pyjamas" class="mw-redirect" title="Pyjamas">pyjamas</a>, loose <a href="/wiki/Shalwar_kameez" title="Shalwar kameez">shalwars</a>, <a href="/wiki/Churidar" title="Churidar">churidars</a>, or less traditionally over <a href="/wiki/Jeans" title="Jeans">jeans</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Shukla2015_452-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shukla2015-452">[439]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the last 50 years, fashions have changed a great deal in India. Increasingly, in urban settings in northern India, the sari is no longer the apparel of everyday wear, transformed instead into one for formal occasions.<sup id="cite_ref-Dwyer2014_453-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dwyer2014-453">[440]</a></sup> The traditional shalwar kameez is rarely worn by younger women, who favour churidars or jeans.<sup id="cite_ref-Dwyer2014_453-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dwyer2014-453">[440]</a></sup> The kurtas worn by young men usually fall to the shins and are seldom plain. In white-collar office settings, ubiquitous air conditioning allows men to wear sports jackets year-round.<sup id="cite_ref-Dwyer2014_453-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dwyer2014-453">[440]</a></sup> For weddings and formal occasions, men in the middle- and upper classes often wear <a href="/wiki/Bandgala" class="mw-redirect" title="Bandgala">bandgala</a>, or short <a href="/wiki/Nehru_jackets" class="mw-redirect" title="Nehru jackets">Nehru jackets</a>, with pants, with the groom and his <a href="/wiki/Groomsmen" class="mw-redirect" title="Groomsmen">groomsmen</a> sporting <a href="/wiki/Sherwani" title="Sherwani">sherwanis</a> and churidars.<sup id="cite_ref-Dwyer2014_453-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dwyer2014-453">[440]</a></sup> The dhoti, the once universal garment of Hindu India, the wearing of which in the homespun and handwoven form of <a href="/wiki/Khadi" title="Khadi">khadi</a> allowed Gandhi to bring Indian nationalism to the millions,<sup id="cite_ref-BruzziGibson2013_454-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BruzziGibson2013-454">[441]</a></sup> is seldom seen in the cities,<sup id="cite_ref-Dwyer2014_453-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dwyer2014-453">[440]</a></sup> reduced now, with brocaded border, to the <a href="/wiki/Liturgical" class="mw-redirect" title="Liturgical">liturgical</a> <a href="/wiki/Vestment" title="Vestment">vestments</a> of Hindu priests. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Indian_cuisine" title="Indian cuisine">Indian cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:432px;max-width:432px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:235px;max-width:235px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:143px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:South_Indian_Thali_Cropped.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/South_Indian_Thali_Cropped.jpg/233px-South_Indian_Thali_Cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="233" height="144" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/South_Indian_Thali_Cropped.jpg/350px-South_Indian_Thali_Cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/South_Indian_Thali_Cropped.jpg/466px-South_Indian_Thali_Cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2567" data-file-height="1583"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           South Indian vegetarian <a href="/wiki/Thali" title="Thali">thali</a>, or platter
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:193px;max-width:193px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:143px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Assamese_Thali.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Assamese_Thali.jpg/191px-Assamese_Thali.jpg" decoding="async" width="191" height="143" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Assamese_Thali.jpg/287px-Assamese_Thali.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Assamese_Thali.jpg/382px-Assamese_Thali.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           An <a href="/wiki/Assam" title="Assam">Assamese</a> thali
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:226px;max-width:226px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:149px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Hyderabadi_Chicken_Biryani.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Hyderabadi_Chicken_Biryani.jpg/224px-Hyderabadi_Chicken_Biryani.jpg" decoding="async" width="224" height="149" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Hyderabadi_Chicken_Biryani.jpg/336px-Hyderabadi_Chicken_Biryani.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Hyderabadi_Chicken_Biryani.jpg/448px-Hyderabadi_Chicken_Biryani.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3888" data-file-height="2592"></a>

          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:149px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Vindalho.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Vindalho.jpg/200px-Vindalho.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Vindalho.jpg/300px-Vindalho.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Vindalho.jpg/400px-Vindalho.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="480"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Pork <a href="/wiki/Vindaloo" title="Vindaloo">vindaloo</a> from <a href="/wiki/Goa" title="Goa">Goa</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:219px;max-width:219px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:162px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Tiffin_wallah_lunch.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Tiffin_wallah_lunch.jpg/217px-Tiffin_wallah_lunch.jpg" decoding="async" width="217" height="163" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Tiffin_wallah_lunch.jpg/326px-Tiffin_wallah_lunch.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Tiffin_wallah_lunch.jpg/434px-Tiffin_wallah_lunch.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Home-cooked lunch delivered to the office by the <a href="/wiki/Tiffin" title="Tiffin">tiffin</a> wallah
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:209px;max-width:209px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:162px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Odia_Mutton_Curry_(Mansha_Tarkari)_Rotated.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Odia_Mutton_Curry_%28Mansha_Tarkari%29_Rotated.jpg/207px-Odia_Mutton_Curry_%28Mansha_Tarkari%29_Rotated.jpg" decoding="async" width="207" height="163" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Odia_Mutton_Curry_%28Mansha_Tarkari%29_Rotated.jpg/311px-Odia_Mutton_Curry_%28Mansha_Tarkari%29_Rotated.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Odia_Mutton_Curry_%28Mansha_Tarkari%29_Rotated.jpg/414px-Odia_Mutton_Curry_%28Mansha_Tarkari%29_Rotated.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1229" data-file-height="966"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Mutton_curry" title="Mutton curry">Railway mutton curry</a> from <a href="/wiki/Odisha" title="Odisha">Odisha</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Indian cuisine consists of a wide variety of regional and traditional cuisines. Given the range of diversity in soil type, climate, culture, ethnic groups, and occupations, these cuisines vary substantially from each other, using locally available spices, herbs, vegetables, and fruit. Indian <a href="/wiki/Foodways" title="Foodways">foodways</a> have been influenced by religion, in particular Hindu cultural choices and traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-Dias1996_455-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dias1996-455">[442]</a></sup> They have been also shaped by Islamic rule, particularly that of the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughals</a>, by the arrival of the <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portuguese</a> on India's southwestern shores, and by British rule. These three influences are reflected, respectively, in the dishes of <a href="/wiki/Pilaf" title="Pilaf">pilaf</a> and <a href="/wiki/Biryani" title="Biryani">biryani</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Vindaloo" title="Vindaloo">vindaloo</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/Tiffin" title="Tiffin">tiffin</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mutton_curry" title="Mutton curry">Railway mutton curry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-GestelandGesteland2010_456-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GestelandGesteland2010-456">[443]</a></sup> Earlier, the <a href="/wiki/Columbian_exchange" title="Columbian exchange">Columbian exchange</a> had brought the potato, the tomato, maize, peanuts, cashew nuts, pineapples, guavas, and most notably, <a href="/wiki/Chilli_peppers" class="mw-redirect" title="Chilli peppers">chilli peppers</a>, to India. Each became staples of use.<sup id="cite_ref-457" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-457">[444]</a></sup> In turn, the <a href="/wiki/Spice_trade" title="Spice trade">spice trade</a> between India and <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> was a catalyst for Europe's <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery">Age of Discovery</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cornillez1999_458-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cornillez1999-458">[445]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Cereal" title="Cereal">cereals</a> grown in India, their choice, times, and regions of planting, correspond strongly to the timing of India's monsoons, and the variation across regions in their associated rainfall.<sup id="cite_ref-sen-colleen-p13_459-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sen-colleen-p13-459">[446]</a></sup> In general, the broad division of cereal zones in India, as determined by their dependence on rain, was firmly in place before the arrival of artificial irrigation.<sup id="cite_ref-sen-colleen-p13_459-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sen-colleen-p13-459">[446]</a></sup> Rice, which requires a lot of water, has been grown traditionally in regions of high rainfall in the northeast and the western coast, wheat in regions of moderate rainfall, like India's northern plains, and millet in regions of low rainfall, such as on the <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Plateau" title="Deccan Plateau">Deccan Plateau</a> and in <a href="/wiki/Rajasthan" title="Rajasthan">Rajasthan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-roger-cambridge-2000_460-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-roger-cambridge-2000-460">[447]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-sen-colleen-p13_459-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sen-colleen-p13-459">[446]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The foundation of a typical Indian meal is a cereal cooked in plain fashion, and complemented with flavourful savoury dishes.<sup id="cite_ref-Davidson2014-p409_461-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davidson2014-p409-461">[448]</a></sup> The latter includes <a href="/wiki/Lentil" title="Lentil">lentils</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pulses" class="mw-redirect" title="Pulses">pulses</a> and vegetables spiced commonly with <a href="/wiki/Ginger_root" class="mw-redirect" title="Ginger root">ginger</a> and <a href="/wiki/Garlic" title="Garlic">garlic</a>, but also more discerningly with a combination of spices that may include <a href="/wiki/Coriander" title="Coriander">coriander</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cumin" title="Cumin">cumin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turmeric" title="Turmeric">turmeric</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinnamon" title="Cinnamon">cinnamon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cardamon" class="mw-redirect" title="Cardamon">cardamon</a> and others as informed by culinary conventions.<sup id="cite_ref-Davidson2014-p409_461-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davidson2014-p409-461">[448]</a></sup> In an actual meal, this mental representation takes the form of a platter, or <a href="/wiki/Thali" title="Thali">thali</a>, with a central place for the cooked cereal, peripheral ones, often in small bowls, for the flavourful accompaniments, and the simultaneous, rather than piecemeal, ingestion of the two in each act of eating, whether by actual mixing—for example of rice and lentils—or in the folding of one—such as bread—around the other, such as cooked vegetables.<sup id="cite_ref-Davidson2014-p409_461-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davidson2014-p409-461">[448]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:206px;max-width:206px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:362px;overflow:hidden">
           <div id="mwe_player_1" class="PopUpMediaTransform" style="width:204px;" videopayload="<div class=&quot;mediaContainer&quot; style=&quot;width:270px&quot;><video id=&quot;mwe_player_2&quot;             <img alt="File:Making Khameeri Roti in Tandoor in Turkman Gate Old Delhi.webm" style="width:204px;height:363px" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Making_Khameeri_Roti_in_Tandoor_in_Turkman_Gate_Old_Delhi.webm/204px--Making_Khameeri_Roti_in_Tandoor_in_Turkman_Gate_Old_Delhi.webm.jpg"><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/81/Making_Khameeri_Roti_in_Tandoor_in_Turkman_Gate_Old_Delhi.webm" title="Play media" target="new"><span class="play-btn-large"><span class="mw-tmh-playtext">Play media</span></span></a>
           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           A tandoor chef in the <a href="/wiki/Turkman_Gate" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkman Gate">Turkman Gate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Old_Delhi" title="Old Delhi">Old Delhi</a>, makes Khameeri <a href="/wiki/Roti" title="Roti">roti</a> (a Muslim-influenced style of <a href="/wiki/Bread#Leavening" title="Bread">leavened bread</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-Panjabi1995_462-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Panjabi1995-462">[449]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>A notable feature of Indian food is the existence of a number of distinctive vegetarian cuisines, each a feature of the geographical and cultural histories of its adherents.<sup id="cite_ref-Davidson2014-p410_463-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davidson2014-p410-463">[450]</a></sup> The appearance of <i><a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahimsa</a></i>, or the avoidance of violence toward all forms of life in many religious orders early in Indian history, especially <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishadic Hinduism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a>, is thought to have been a notable factor in the prevalence of vegetarianism among a segment of India's Hindu population, especially in southern India, Gujarat, and the <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a>-speaking belt of north-central India, as well as among Jains.<sup id="cite_ref-Davidson2014-p410_463-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davidson2014-p410-463">[450]</a></sup> Among these groups, strong discomfort is felt at thoughts of eating meat,<sup id="cite_ref-SahakianSaloma2016-50_464-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SahakianSaloma2016-50-464">[451]</a></sup> and contributes to the low proportional consumption of meat to overall diet in India.<sup id="cite_ref-SahakianSaloma2016-50_464-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SahakianSaloma2016-50-464">[451]</a></sup> Unlike China, which has increased its per capita meat consumption substantially in its years of increased economic growth, in India the strong dietary traditions have contributed to dairy, rather than meat, becoming the preferred form of animal protein consumption accompanying higher economic growth.<sup id="cite_ref-OECDNations2018_465-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECDNations2018-465">[452]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the last millennium, the most significant import of cooking techniques into India occurred during the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a>. The cultivation of rice had spread much earlier from India to <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central</a> and <a href="/wiki/West_Asia" class="mw-redirect" title="West Asia">West Asia</a>; however, it was during Mughal rule that dishes, such as the <a href="/wiki/Pilaf" title="Pilaf">pilaf</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-roger-cambridge-2000_460-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-roger-cambridge-2000-460">[447]</a></sup> developed in the interim during the <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_caliphate" class="mw-redirect" title="Abbasid caliphate">Abbasid caliphate</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-sengupta-74_466-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sengupta-74-466">[453]</a></sup> and cooking techniques such as the marinating of meat in yogurt, spread into northern India from regions to its northwest.<sup id="cite_ref-CollinghamCollingham2007_467-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CollinghamCollingham2007-467">[454]</a></sup> To the simple yogurt marinade of Persia, onions, garlic, almonds, and spices began to be added in India.<sup id="cite_ref-CollinghamCollingham2007_467-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CollinghamCollingham2007-467">[454]</a></sup> Rice grown to the southwest of the Mughal capital, <a href="/wiki/Agra" title="Agra">Agra</a>, which had become famous in the Islamic world for its fine grain, was partially cooked and layered alternately with the sauteed meat, the pot sealed tightly, and slow cooked according to another Persian cooking technique, to produce what has today become the Indian <a href="/wiki/Biryani" title="Biryani">biryani</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-CollinghamCollingham2007_467-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CollinghamCollingham2007-467">[454]</a></sup> a feature of festive dining in many parts of India.<sup id="cite_ref-nandy2004_468-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nandy2004-468">[455]</a></sup> In food served in restaurants in urban north India, and internationally, the diversity of Indian food has been partially concealed by the dominance of <a href="/wiki/Punjabi_cuisine" title="Punjabi cuisine">Punjabi cuisine</a>. This was caused in large part by an entrepreneurial response among people from the <a href="/wiki/Punjab" title="Punjab">Punjab</a> region who had been displaced by the 1947 <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">partition of India</a>, and had arrived in India as refugees.<sup id="cite_ref-Davidson2014-p410_463-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davidson2014-p410-463">[450]</a></sup> The identification of Indian cuisine with the <a href="/wiki/Tandoori_chicken" title="Tandoori chicken">tandoori chicken</a>—cooked in the <a href="/wiki/Tandoor" title="Tandoor">tandoor</a> oven, which had traditionally been used for baking bread in the rural Punjab and the Delhi region, especially among Muslims, but which is originally from <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>—dates to this period.<sup id="cite_ref-Davidson2014-p410_463-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davidson2014-p410-463">[450]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports_and_recreation">Sports and recreation</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_India" title="Sport in India">Sport in India</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:442px;max-width:442px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:440px;max-width:440px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:114px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Sachin_Tendulkar_about_to_score_14000th_run_in_test_cricket.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Sachin_Tendulkar_about_to_score_14000th_run_in_test_cricket.jpg/438px-Sachin_Tendulkar_about_to_score_14000th_run_in_test_cricket.jpg" decoding="async" width="438" height="114" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Sachin_Tendulkar_about_to_score_14000th_run_in_test_cricket.jpg/657px-Sachin_Tendulkar_about_to_score_14000th_run_in_test_cricket.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Sachin_Tendulkar_about_to_score_14000th_run_in_test_cricket.jpg/876px-Sachin_Tendulkar_about_to_score_14000th_run_in_test_cricket.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2650" data-file-height="690"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Indian <a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">cricketer</a> <a href="/wiki/Sachin_Tendulkar" title="Sachin Tendulkar">Sachin Tendulkar</a> about to score a record 14,000 runs in <a href="/wiki/Test_cricket" title="Test cricket">test cricket</a> while playing against Australia in <a href="/wiki/Bangalore" title="Bangalore">Bangalore</a>, 2010.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">Cricket</a> is the most popular sport in India.<sup id="cite_ref-469" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-469">[456]</a></sup> Major domestic competitions include the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Premier_League" title="Indian Premier League">Indian Premier League</a>, which is the most-watched cricket league in the world and ranks sixth among all sports leagues.<sup id="cite_ref-470" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-470">[457]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Several traditional indigenous sports remain fairly popular, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Kabaddi" title="Kabaddi">kabaddi</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Kho_kho" title="Kho kho">kho kho</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Pehlwani" title="Pehlwani">pehlwani</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Gilli-danda" class="mw-redirect" title="Gilli-danda">gilli-danda</a></i>. Some of the earliest forms of Asian <a href="/wiki/Indian_martial_arts" title="Indian martial arts">martial arts</a>, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Kalarippayattu" class="mw-redirect" title="Kalarippayattu">Kalarippayattu</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Musti_yuddha" class="mw-redirect" title="Musti yuddha">musti yuddha</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Silambam" title="Silambam">silambam</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Marma_adi" class="mw-redirect" title="Marma adi">marma adi</a></i>, originated in India. <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">Chess</a>, commonly held to have <a href="/wiki/History_of_chess#India" title="History of chess">originated in India</a> as <i><a href="/wiki/Chaturanga" title="Chaturanga">chaturaṅga</a></i>, is regaining widespread popularity with the rise in the number of Indian <a href="/wiki/Grandmaster_(chess)" title="Grandmaster (chess)">grandmasters</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWolpert20032_471-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWolpert20032-471">[458]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERediff_2008_b_472-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERediff_2008_b-472">[459]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Pachisi" title="Pachisi">Pachisi</a></i>, from which <a href="/wiki/Parcheesi" title="Parcheesi">parcheesi</a> derives, was played on a giant marble court by <a href="/wiki/Akbar" title="Akbar">Akbar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBinmore200798_473-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBinmore200798-473">[460]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The improved results garnered by the <a href="/wiki/India_Davis_Cup_team" title="India Davis Cup team">Indian Davis Cup team</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Category:Indian_tennis_players" title="Category:Indian tennis players">Indian tennis players</a> in the early 2010s have made tennis increasingly popular in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Wall_Street_Journal_2009_474-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Wall_Street_Journal_2009-474">[461]</a></sup> India has a <a href="/wiki/Category:Indian_sport_shooters" title="Category:Indian sport shooters">comparatively strong presence</a> in shooting sports, and has won several medals at the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympics</a>, the <a href="/wiki/ISSF_World_Shooting_Championships" title="ISSF World Shooting Championships">World Shooting Championships</a>, and the Commonwealth Games.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBritish_Broadcasting_Corporation_2010_b_475-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBritish_Broadcasting_Corporation_2010_b-475">[462]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Times_of_India_2010_476-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Times_of_India_2010-476">[463]</a></sup> Other sports in which Indians have succeeded internationally include <a href="/wiki/Badminton" title="Badminton">badminton</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBritish_Broadcasting_Corporation_2010_a_477-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBritish_Broadcasting_Corporation_2010_a-477">[464]</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/Saina_Nehwal" title="Saina Nehwal">Saina Nehwal</a> and <a href="/wiki/P._V._Sindhu" title="P. V. Sindhu">P V Sindhu</a> are two of the top-ranked female badminton players in the world), boxing,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMint_2010_478-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMint_2010-478">[465]</a></sup> and wrestling.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEXavier2010_479-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEXavier2010-479">[466]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Football_in_India" title="Football in India">Football</a> is popular in <a href="/wiki/West_Bengal" title="West Bengal">West Bengal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Goa" title="Goa">Goa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tamil_Nadu" title="Tamil Nadu">Tamil Nadu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kerala" title="Kerala">Kerala</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Sister_States" class="mw-redirect" title="Seven Sister States">north-eastern states</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMajumdarBandyopadhyay20061–5_480-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMajumdarBandyopadhyay20061–5-480">[467]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:138px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Filles_jouant_%C3%A0_la_marelle,_Jaura,_Inde.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Filles_jouant_%C3%A0_la_marelle%2C_Jaura%2C_Inde.jpg/208px-Filles_jouant_%C3%A0_la_marelle%2C_Jaura%2C_Inde.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="139" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Filles_jouant_%C3%A0_la_marelle%2C_Jaura%2C_Inde.jpg/312px-Filles_jouant_%C3%A0_la_marelle%2C_Jaura%2C_Inde.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Filles_jouant_%C3%A0_la_marelle%2C_Jaura%2C_Inde.jpg/416px-Filles_jouant_%C3%A0_la_marelle%2C_Jaura%2C_Inde.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3888" data-file-height="2592"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Girls play <a href="/wiki/Hopscotch" title="Hopscotch">hopscotch</a> in <a href="/wiki/Jaora" title="Jaora">Jaora</a>, Madhya Pradesh. Hopscotch has been commonly played by girls in rural India.<sup id="cite_ref-SrinivasanJermyn2001_481-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SrinivasanJermyn2001-481">[468]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>India has hosted or co-hosted several international sporting events: the <a href="/wiki/1951_Asian_Games" title="1951 Asian Games">1951</a> and <a href="/wiki/1982_Asian_Games" title="1982 Asian Games">1982 Asian Games</a>; the <a href="/wiki/1987_Cricket_World_Cup" title="1987 Cricket World Cup">1987</a>, <a href="/wiki/1996_Cricket_World_Cup" title="1996 Cricket World Cup">1996</a>, and <a href="/wiki/2011_Cricket_World_Cup" title="2011 Cricket World Cup">2011 Cricket World Cup</a> tournaments; the <a href="/wiki/2003_Afro-Asian_Games" title="2003 Afro-Asian Games">2003 Afro-Asian Games</a>; the <a href="/wiki/2006_ICC_Champions_Trophy" title="2006 ICC Champions Trophy">2006 ICC Champions Trophy</a>; the <a href="/wiki/2010_Men%27s_Hockey_World_Cup" title="2010 Men's Hockey World Cup">2010 Hockey World Cup</a>; the <a href="/wiki/2010_Commonwealth_Games" title="2010 Commonwealth Games">2010 Commonwealth Games</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/2017_FIFA_U-17_World_Cup" title="2017 FIFA U-17 World Cup">2017 FIFA U-17 World Cup</a>. Major international sporting events held annually in India include the <a href="/wiki/Chennai_Open" class="mw-redirect" title="Chennai Open">Chennai Open</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Marathon" title="Mumbai Marathon">Mumbai Marathon</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Half_Marathon" title="Delhi Half Marathon">Delhi Half Marathon</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Masters" title="Indian Masters">Indian Masters</a>. The first <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula 1</a> <a href="/wiki/Indian_Grand_Prix" title="Indian Grand Prix">Indian Grand Prix</a> featured in late 2011 but has been discontinued from the F1 season calendar since 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDehejia2011_482-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDehejia2011-482">[469]</a></sup> India has traditionally been the dominant country at the <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_Games" title="South Asian Games">South Asian Games</a>. An example of this dominance is the <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_South_Asian_Games" title="Basketball at the South Asian Games">basketball competition</a> where the <a href="/wiki/India_national_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="India national basketball team">Indian team</a> won three out of four tournaments to date.<sup id="cite_ref-483" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-483">[470]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r936637989">.mw-parser-output .portal{border:solid #aaa 1px;padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style>
      <div role="navigation" aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portal plainlist tright"> 
       <ul> 
        <li><span><img alt="flag" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/41/Flag_of_India.svg/32px-Flag_of_India.svg.png" decoding="async" width="32" height="21" class="noviewer thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/41/Flag_of_India.svg/48px-Flag_of_India.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/41/Flag_of_India.svg/64px-Flag_of_India.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1350" data-file-height="900"></span><span><a href="/wiki/Portal:India" title="Portal:India">India portal</a></span></li> 
        <li><span><a href="/wiki/File:Asia_(orthographic_projection).svg" class="image"><img alt="icon" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/28px-Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="28" height="28" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/42px-Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/56px-Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="541" data-file-height="541"></a></span><span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Asia" title="Portal:Asia">Asia portal</a></span></li>
