      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_India" title="Outline of India">Outline of India</a></li>
      </ul> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style>
      <div class="reflist reflist-columns references-column-width reflist-lower-alpha" style="column-width: 33em;"> 
       <ol class="references"> 
        <li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"[...] <i>Jana Gana Mana</i> is the National Anthem of India, subject to such alterations in the words as the Government may authorise as occasion arises; and the song <i>Vande Mataram</i>, which has played a historic part in the struggle for Indian freedom, shall be honoured equally with <i>Jana Gana Mana</i> and shall have equal status with it."(<a href="#CITEREFConstituent_Assembly_of_India1950">Constituent Assembly of India 1950</a>).</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to <a href="/wiki/Part_XVII_of_the_Constitution_of_India" title="Part XVII of the Constitution of India">Part XVII of the Constitution of India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Standard_Hindi" class="mw-redirect" title="Standard Hindi">Hindi</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a> script is the <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official language</a> of the Union, along with <a href="/wiki/Indian_English" title="Indian English">English</a> as an additional official language.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Home_Affairs_1960_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Home_Affairs_1960-6">[5]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENational_Informatics_Centre2005_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENational_Informatics_Centre2005-1">[1]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-india.gov.in2_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-india.gov.in2-7">[6]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/States_and_union_territories_of_India" title="States and union territories of India">States and union territories</a> can have a different official language of their own other than Hindi or English.</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-16">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Different sources give widely differing figures, primarily based on how the terms "language" and "dialect" are defined and grouped. Ethnologue, produced by the Christian evangelist organisation SIL International, lists 461 tongues for India (out of 6,912 worldwide), 447 of which are living, while 14 are extinct.<sup id="cite_ref-Ethnologue_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnologue-14">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ethnologue2_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnologue2-15">[13]</a></sup></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-18">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"The country's exact size is subject to debate because some borders are disputed. The Indian government lists the total area as 3,287,260&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (1,269,220&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) and the total land area as 3,060,500&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (1,181,700&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi); the United Nations lists the total area as 3,287,263&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (1,269,219&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) and total land area as 2,973,190&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (1,147,960&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi)."(<a href="#CITEREFLibrary_of_Congress2004">Library of Congress 2004</a>).</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-26">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See <a href="/wiki/Date_and_time_notation_in_India" title="Date and time notation in India">Date and time notation in India</a>.</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-29">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India" title="Government of India">Government of India</a> also regards <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> as a bordering country, as it considers all of <a href="/wiki/Kashmir" title="Kashmir">Kashmir</a> to be part of India. However, this is <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_conflict" title="Kashmir conflict">disputed</a>, and the region bordering Afghanistan is administered by Pakistan. Source: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r999302996">.mw-parser-output cite.citation{font-style:inherit}.mw-parser-output .citation q{quotes:"\"""\"""'""'"}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-free a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-free a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/65/Lock-green.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .id-lock-registration a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-registration a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Lock-gray-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-subscription a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-subscription a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/aa/Lock-red-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-subscription,.mw-parser-output .cs1-registration{color:#555}.mw-parser-output .cs1-subscription span,.mw-parser-output .cs1-registration span{border-bottom:1px dotted;cursor:help}.mw-parser-output .cs1-ws-icon a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg")right 0.1em center/12px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output code.cs1-code{color:inherit;background:inherit;border:none;padding:inherit}.mw-parser-output .cs1-hidden-error{display:none;font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-visible-error{font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{display:none;color:#33aa33;margin-left:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-format{font-size:95%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-left,.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-wl-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right,.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-wl-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}</style><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150317182910/http://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/BMIntro-1011.pdf">"Ministry of Home Affairs (Department of Border Management)"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/BMIntro-1011.pdf">the original</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> on 17 March 2015<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">1 September</span> 2008</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Ministry+of+Home+Affairs+%28Department+of+Border+Management%29&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fmha.nic.in%2Fsites%2Fupload_files%2Fmha%2Ffiles%2FBMIntro-1011.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-42"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-42">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"A Chinese pilgrim also recorded evidence of the caste system as he could observe it. According to this evidence the treatment meted out to untouchables such as the Chandalas was very similar to that which they experienced in later periods. This would contradict assertions that this rigid form of the caste system emerged in India only as a reaction to the Islamic conquest."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200493_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200493-41">[35]</a></sup></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-51"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-51">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Shah Jahan eventually sent her body 800&nbsp;km (500 mi) to Agra for burial in the Rauza-i Munauwara ("Illuminated Tomb") – a personal tribute and a stone manifestation of his imperial power. This tomb has been celebrated globally as the Taj Mahal."<sup id="cite_ref-Fisher2018-106_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fisher2018-106-50">[43]</a></sup></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-177"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-177">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The northernmost point under Indian control is the disputed <a href="/wiki/Siachen_Glacier" title="Siachen Glacier">Siachen Glacier</a> in <a href="/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(union_territory)" title="Jammu and Kashmir (union territory)">Jammu and Kashmir</a>; however, the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India" title="Government of India">Government of India</a> regards the entire region of the former princely state of Jammu and Kashmir, including the <a href="/wiki/Gilgit-Baltistan" title="Gilgit-Baltistan">Gilgit-Baltistan</a> administered by Pakistan, to be its territory. It therefore assigns the latitude 37° 6′ to its northernmost point.</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-197"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-197">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A biodiversity hotspot is a <a href="/wiki/Biogeography" title="Biogeography">biogeographical</a> region which has more than 1,500 <a href="/wiki/Vascular_plant" title="Vascular plant">vascular plant</a> species, but less than 30% of its primary habitat.<sup id="cite_ref-SivaperumanVenkataraman2018_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SivaperumanVenkataraman2018-196">[187]</a></sup></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-211"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-211">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A forest cover is <i>moderately dense</i> if between 40% and 70% of its area is covered by its tree canopy.</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-337"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-337">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In 2015, the World Bank raised its international poverty line to $1.90 per day.<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[325]</a></sup></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-remaining_religions-365"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-remaining_religions_365-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Besides specific religions, the last two categories in the 2011 Census were "Other religions and persuasions" (0.65%) and "Religion not stated" (0.23%).</span> </li> 
       </ol>
      </div>

        <li id="cite_note-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-27">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.worldstandards.eu/cars/list-of-left-driving-countries/">"List of all left- &amp; right-driving countries around the world"</a>. <i>worldstandards.eu</i>. 13 May 2020<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">10 June</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=worldstandards.eu&amp;rft.atitle=List+of+all+left-+%26+right-driving+countries+around+the+world&amp;rft.date=2020-05-13&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.worldstandards.eu%2Fcars%2Flist-of-left-driving-countries%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-28"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-28">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">–
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation cs2"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=yjcOAQAAMAAJ&amp;pg=PA76"><i>The Essential Desk Reference</i></a>, Oxford University Press, 2002, p.&nbsp;76, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-512873-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-512873-4"><bdi>978-0-19-512873-4</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Essential+Desk+Reference&amp;rft.pages=76&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-512873-4&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DyjcOAQAAMAAJ%26pg%3DPA76&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span> "Official name: Republic of India.";<br>–

          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation cs2"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Co_VIPIJerIC&amp;pg=PA515"><i>Merriam-Webster's Geographical Dictionary</i></a> (3rd&nbsp;ed.), <a href="/wiki/Merriam-Webster" title="Merriam-Webster">Merriam-Webster</a>, 1997, pp.&nbsp;515–516, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-87779-546-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-87779-546-9"><bdi>978-0-87779-546-9</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Merriam-Webster%27s+Geographical+Dictionary&amp;rft.pages=515-516&amp;rft.edition=3rd&amp;rft.pub=Merriam-Webster&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-87779-546-9&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DCo_VIPIJerIC%26pg%3DPA515&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span> "Officially, Republic of India";<br>–
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation cs2"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=O5moCwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA54-IA10"><i>Complete Atlas of the World, 3rd Edition: The Definitive View of the Earth</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/DK_Publishing" class="mw-redirect" title="DK Publishing">DK Publishing</a>, 2016, p.&nbsp;54, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4654-5528-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4654-5528-4"><bdi>978-1-4654-5528-4</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Complete+Atlas+of+the+World%2C+3rd+Edition%3A+The+Definitive+View+of+the+Earth&amp;rft.pages=54&amp;rft.pub=DK+Publishing&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4654-5528-4&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DO5moCwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA54-IA10&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span> "Official name: Republic of India";<br>–
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation cs2"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=CQWhAQAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA726"><i>Worldwide Government Directory with Intergovernmental Organizations 2013</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/CQ_Press" title="CQ Press">CQ Press</a>, 10 May 2013, p.&nbsp;726, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4522-9937-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4522-9937-2"><bdi>978-1-4522-9937-2</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Worldwide+Government+Directory+with+Intergovernmental+Organizations+2013&amp;rft.pages=726&amp;rft.pub=CQ+Press&amp;rft.date=2013-05-10&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4522-9937-2&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DCQWhAQAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA726&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span> "India (Republic of India; Bharat Ganarajya)"</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Combined-3-Out-of-Africa-30"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Combined-3-Out-of-Africa_30-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"> (a) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDyson2018" class="citation cs2">Dyson, Tim (2018), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3TRtDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA1"><i>A Population History of India: From the First Modern People to the Present Day</i></a>, Oxford University Press, p.&nbsp;1, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-882905-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-882905-8"><bdi>978-0-19-882905-8</bdi></a>, <q>Modern human beings—Homo sapiens—originated in Africa. Then, intermittently, sometime between 60,000 and 80,000 years ago, tiny groups of them began to enter the north-west of the Indian subcontinent. It seems likely that initially they came by way of the coast. ... it is virtually certain that there were Homo sapiens in the subcontinent 55,000 years ago, even though the earliest fossils that have been found of them date to only about 30,000 years before the present. (page 1)</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Population+History+of+India%3A+From+the+First+Modern+People+to+the+Present+Day&amp;rft.pages=1&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-882905-8&amp;rft.aulast=Dyson&amp;rft.aufirst=Tim&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D3TRtDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA1&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span><br> (b) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMichael_D._PetragliaBridget_Allchin2007" class="citation book cs1">Michael D. Petraglia; <a href="/wiki/Bridget_Allchin" title="Bridget Allchin">Bridget Allchin</a> (22 May 2007). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Qm9GfjNlnRwC&amp;pg=PA10"><i>The Evolution and History of Human Populations in South Asia: Inter-disciplinary Studies in Archaeology, Biological Anthropology, Linguistics and Genetics</i></a>. Springer Science &amp; Business Media. p.&nbsp;6. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4020-5562-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4020-5562-1"><bdi>978-1-4020-5562-1</bdi></a>. <q>Y-Chromosome and Mt-DNA data support the colonization of South Asia by modern humans originating in Africa. ... Coalescence dates for most non-European populations average to between 73–55 ka.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Evolution+and+History+of+Human+Populations+in+South+Asia%3A+Inter-disciplinary+Studies+in+Archaeology%2C+Biological+Anthropology%2C+Linguistics+and+Genetics&amp;rft.pages=6&amp;rft.pub=Springer+Science+%26+Business+Media&amp;rft.date=2007-05-22&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4020-5562-1&amp;rft.au=Michael+D.+Petraglia&amp;rft.au=Bridget+Allchin&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DQm9GfjNlnRwC%26pg%3DPA10&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span> <br> (c)
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFFisher2018" class="citation cs2">Fisher, Michael H. (2018), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=kZVuDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA23"><i>An Environmental History of India: From Earliest Times to the Twenty-First Century</i></a>, Cambridge University Press, p.&nbsp;23, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-107-11162-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-107-11162-2"><bdi>978-1-107-11162-2</bdi></a>, <q>Scholars estimate that the first successful expansion of the Homo sapiens range beyond Africa and across the Arabian Peninsula occurred from as early as 80,000 years ago to as late as 40,000 years ago, although there may have been prior unsuccessful emigrations. Some of their descendants extended the human range ever further in each generation, spreading into each habitable land they encountered. One human channel was along the warm and productive coastal lands of the Persian Gulf and northern Indian Ocean. Eventually, various bands entered India between 75,000 years ago and 35,000 years ago. (page 23)</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=An+Environmental+History+of+India%3A+From+Earliest+Times+to+the+Twenty-First+Century&amp;rft.pages=23&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-107-11162-2&amp;rft.aulast=Fisher&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael+H.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DkZVuDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA23&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Dyson2018-28a-31"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Dyson2018-28a_31-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"> 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDyson2018" class="citation cs2">Dyson, Tim (2018), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3TRtDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA28"><i>A Population History of India: From the First Modern People to the Present Day</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>, p.&nbsp;28, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-882905-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-882905-8"><bdi>978-0-19-882905-8</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Population+History+of+India%3A+From+the+First+Modern+People+to+the+Present+Day&amp;rft.pages=28&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-882905-8&amp;rft.aulast=Dyson&amp;rft.aufirst=Tim&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D3TRtDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA28&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Combined-2-32"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Combined-2_32-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"> (a) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDyson2018" class="citation cs2">Dyson, Tim (2018), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3TRtDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA4"><i>A Population History of India: From the First Modern People to the Present Day</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>, pp.&nbsp;4–5, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-882905-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-882905-8"><bdi>978-0-19-882905-8</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Population+History+of+India%3A+From+the+First+Modern+People+to+the+Present+Day&amp;rft.pages=4-5&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-882905-8&amp;rft.aulast=Dyson&amp;rft.aufirst=Tim&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D3TRtDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA4&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span>; (b) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFFisher2018" class="citation cs2">Fisher, Michael H. (2018), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=kZVuDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA23"><i>An Environmental History of India: From Earliest Times to the Twenty-First Century</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Cambridge_University_Press" title="Cambridge University Press">Cambridge University Press</a>, p.&nbsp;33, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-107-11162-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-107-11162-2"><bdi>978-1-107-11162-2</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=An+Environmental+History+of+India%3A+From+Earliest+Times+to+the+Twenty-First+Century&amp;rft.pages=33&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-107-11162-2&amp;rft.aulast=Fisher&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael+H.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DkZVuDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA23&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Combined-4-Rigveda-33"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Combined-4-Rigveda_33-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"> (a) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFLowe2015" class="citation book cs1">Lowe, John J. (2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=L07CBwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA2"><i>Participles in Rigvedic Sanskrit: The syntax and semantics of adjectival verb forms</i></a>. Oxford University Press. pp.&nbsp;1–2. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-100505-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-100505-3"><bdi>978-0-19-100505-3</bdi></a>. <q>(The Rigveda) consists of 1,028 hymns (suktas), highly crafted poetic compositions originally intended for recital during rituals and for the invocation of and communication with the Indo-Aryan gods. Modern scholarly opinion largely agrees that these hymns were composed between around 1500&nbsp;BCE and 1200&nbsp;BCE, during the eastward migration of the Indo-Aryan tribes from the mountains of what is today northern Afghanistan across the Punjab into north India.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Participles+in+Rigvedic+Sanskrit%3A+The+syntax+and+semantics+of+adjectival+verb+forms&amp;rft.pages=1-2&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-100505-3&amp;rft.aulast=Lowe&amp;rft.aufirst=John+J.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DL07CBwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA2&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span>, <br> 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFWitzel2008" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Michael_Witzel" title="Michael Witzel">Witzel, Michael</a> (2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=SKBxa-MNqA8C&amp;pg=PA68">"Vedas and Upanisads"</a>. In Gavin Flood (ed.). <i>The Blackwell Companion to Hinduism</i>. John Wiley &amp; Sons. pp.&nbsp;68–70. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-470-99868-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-470-99868-7"><bdi>978-0-470-99868-7</bdi></a>. <q>It is known from internal evidence that the Vedic texts were orally composed in northern India, at first in the Greater Punjab and later on also in more eastern areas, including northern Bihar, between ca. 1500 BCE and ca. 500–400 BCE. The oldest text, the Rgveda, must have been more or less contemporary with the Mitanni texts of northern Syria/Iraq (1450–1350 BCE); ... The Vedic texts were orally composed and transmitted, without the use of script, in an unbroken line of transmission from teacher to student that was formalized early on. This ensured an impeccable textual transmission superior to the classical texts of other cultures; it is in fact something of a <i>tape-recording</i> of ca. 1500–500 BCE. Not just the actual words, but even the long-lost musical (tonal) accent (as in old Greek or in Japanese) has been preserved up to the present. (pp. 68–69) ... The RV text was composed before the introduction and massive use of iron, that is before ca. 1200–1000 BCE. (p. 70)</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Vedas+and+Upanisads&amp;rft.btitle=The+Blackwell+Companion+to+Hinduism&amp;rft.pages=68-70&amp;rft.pub=John+Wiley+%26+Sons&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-470-99868-7&amp;rft.aulast=Witzel&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DSKBxa-MNqA8C%26pg%3DPA68&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span> <br> (c) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDoniger2014" class="citation cs2"><a href="/wiki/Wendy_Doniger" title="Wendy Doniger">Doniger, Wendy</a> (3 February 2014), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=fUnaAgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PR18"><i>On Hinduism</i></a>, Oxford University Press, pp.&nbsp;xviii, 10, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-936009-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-936009-3"><bdi>978-0-19-936009-3</bdi></a>, <q>A Chronology of Hinduism: ca. 1500-1000 BCE Rig Veda; ca. 1200-900 BCE Yajur Veda, Sama Veda and Atharva Veda (p. xviii); Hindu texts began with the <i>Rig Veda</i> ('Knowledge of Verses'), composed in northwest India around 1500 BCE (p. 10)</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=On+Hinduism&amp;rft.pages=xviii%2C+10&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2014-02-03&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-936009-3&amp;rft.aulast=Doniger&amp;rft.aufirst=Wendy&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DfUnaAgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPR18&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span> <br> (d) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFLudden2013" class="citation cs2">Ludden, David (2013), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=EbFHAQAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA19"><i>India and South Asia: A Short History</i></a>, Oneworld Publications, p.&nbsp;19, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-78074-108-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-78074-108-6"><bdi>978-1-78074-108-6</bdi></a>, <q>In Punjab, a dry region with grasslands watered by five rivers (hence ‘panch’ and ‘ab’) draining the western Himalayas, one prehistoric culture left no material remains, but some of its ritual texts were preserved orally over the millennia. The culture is called Aryan, and evidence in its texts indicates that it spread slowly south-east, following the course of the Yamuna and Ganga Rivers. Its elite called itself Arya (pure) and distinguished themselves sharply from others. Aryans led kin groups organized as nomadic horse-herding tribes. Their ritual texts are called Vedas, composed in Sanskrit. <a href="/wiki/Vedic_Sanskrit" title="Vedic Sanskrit">Vedic Sanskrit</a> is recorded only in hymns that were part of Vedic rituals to Aryan gods. To be Aryan apparently meant to belong to the elite among pastoral tribes. Texts that record Aryan culture are not precisely datable, but they seem to begin around 1200 BCE with four collections of Vedic hymns (Rg, Sama, Yajur, and Artharva).</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=India+and+South+Asia%3A+A+Short+History&amp;rft.pages=19&amp;rft.pub=Oneworld+Publications&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-78074-108-6&amp;rft.aulast=Ludden&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DEbFHAQAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA19&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span> <br> (e) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDyson2018" class="citation cs2">Dyson, Tim (2018), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3TRtDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA14"><i>A Population History of India: From the First Modern People to the Present Day</i></a>, Oxford University Press, pp.&nbsp;14–15, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-882905-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-882905-8"><bdi>978-0-19-882905-8</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Population+History+of+India%3A+From+the+First+Modern+People+to+the+Present+Day&amp;rft.pages=14-15&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-882905-8&amp;rft.aulast=Dyson&amp;rft.aufirst=Tim&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D3TRtDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA14&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span> Quote: "Although the collapse of the Indus valley civilization is no longer believed to have been due to an ‘Aryan invasion’ it is widely thought that, at roughly the same time, or perhaps a few centuries later, new Indo-Aryan-speaking people and influences began to enter the subcontinent from the north-west. Detailed evidence is lacking. Nevertheless, a predecessor of the language that would eventually be called Sanskrit was probably introduced into the north-west sometime between 3,900 and 3,000 years ago. This language was related to one then spoken in eastern Iran; and both of these languages belonged to the Indo-European language family. ... It seems likely that various small-scale migrations were involved in the gradual introduction of the predecessor language and associated cultural characteristics. However, there may not have been a tight relationship between movements of people on the one hand, and changes in language and culture on the other. Moreover, the process whereby a dynamic new force gradually arose—a people with a distinct ideology who eventually seem to have referred to themselves as ‘Arya’—was certainly two-way. That is, it involved a blending of new features which came from outside with other features—probably including some surviving Harappan influences—that were already present. Anyhow, it would be quite a few centuries before Sanskrit was written down. And the hymns and stories of the Arya people—especially the Vedas and the later Mahabharata and Ramayana epics—are poor guides as to historical events. Of course, the emerging Arya were to have a huge impact on the history of the subcontinent. Nevertheless, little is known about their early presence."; <br> (f) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFRobb2011" class="citation cs2">Robb, Peter (2011), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=GQ-2VH1LO_EC&amp;pg=PA46"><i>A History of India</i></a>, Macmillan, pp.&nbsp;46–, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-230-34549-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-230-34549-2"><bdi>978-0-230-34549-2</bdi></a>, <q>The expansion of Aryan culture is supposed to have begun around 1500 BCE. It should not be thought that this Aryan emergence (though it implies some migration) necessarily meant either a sudden invasion of new peoples, or a complete break with earlier traditions. It comprises a set of cultural ideas and practices, upheld by a Sanskrit-speaking elite, or Aryans. The features of this society are recorded in the Vedas.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+India&amp;rft.pages=46-&amp;rft.pub=Macmillan&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-230-34549-2&amp;rft.aulast=Robb&amp;rft.aufirst=Peter&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DGQ-2VH1LO_EC%26pg%3DPA46&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Combined-3-34"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Combined-3_34-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"> (a) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFJamisonBrereton2020" class="citation cs2"><a href="/wiki/Stephanie_W._Jamison" title="Stephanie W. Jamison">Jamison, Stephanie</a>; Brereton, Joel (2020), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=1LTRDwAAQBAJ"><i>The Rigveda</i></a>, Oxford University Press, pp.&nbsp;2, 4, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-063339-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-063339-4"><bdi>978-0-19-063339-4</bdi></a>, <q>The RgVeda is one of the four Vedas, which together constitute the oldest texts in Sanskrit and the earliest evidence for what will become Hinduism. (p. 2) Although Vedic religion is very different in many regards from what is known as Classical Hinduism, the seeds are there. Gods like Visnu and Siva (under the name Rudra), who will become so dominant later, are already present in the Rgveda, though in roles both lesser than and different from those they will later play, and the principal Rgvedic gods like Indra remain in later Hinduism, though in diminished capacity (p. 4).</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Rigveda&amp;rft.pages=2%2C+4&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2020&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-063339-4&amp;rft.aulast=Jamison&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephanie&amp;rft.au=Brereton%2C+Joel&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D1LTRDwAAQBAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span>; <br> (b) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFFlood2020" class="citation cs2"><a href="/wiki/Gavin_Flood" title="Gavin Flood">Flood, Gavin</a> (20 August 2020), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=4yT3DwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA4">"Introduction"</a>, in Gavin Flood (ed.), <i>The Oxford History of Hinduism: Hindu Practice: Hindu Practice</i>, OUP Oxford, pp.&nbsp;4–, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-105322-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-105322-1"><bdi>978-0-19-105322-1</bdi></a>, <q>I take the term ‘Hinduism to meaningfully denote a range and history of practice characterized by a number of features, particularly reference to Vedic textual and sacrificial origins, belonging to endogamous social units (jati/varna), participating in practices that involve making an offering to a deity and receiving a blessing (puja), and a first-level cultural polytheism (although many Hindus adhere to a second-level monotheism in which many gods are regarded as emanations or manifestations of the one, supreme being).</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Introduction&amp;rft.btitle=The+Oxford+History+of+Hinduism%3A+Hindu+Practice%3A+Hindu+Practice&amp;rft.pages=4-&amp;rft.pub=OUP+Oxford&amp;rft.date=2020-08-20&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-105322-1&amp;rft.aulast=Flood&amp;rft.aufirst=Gavin&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D4yT3DwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA4&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span>; <br> (c) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMichaels2017" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Axel_Michaels" title="Axel Michaels">Michaels, Axel</a> (2017). Patrick Olivelle, Donald R. Davis (ed.). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=QAJCDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA86"><i>The Oxford History of Hinduism: Hindu Law: A New History of Dharmaśāstra</i></a>. Oxford: Oxford University Press. pp.&nbsp;86–97. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-100709-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-100709-5"><bdi>978-0-19-100709-5</bdi></a>. <q>Almost all traditional Hindu families observe until today at least three <i>samskaras</i> (initiation, marriage, and death ritual). Most other rituals have lost their popularity, are combined with other rites of passage, or are drastically shortened. Although <i>samskaras</i> vary from region to region, from class (<i>varna</i>) to class, and from caste to caste, their core elements remain the same owing to the common source, the Veda, and a common priestly tradition preserved by the <i>Brahmin</i> priests. (p 86)</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Oxford+History+of+Hinduism%3A+Hindu+Law%3A+A+New+History+of+Dharma%C5%9B%C4%81stra&amp;rft.place=Oxford&amp;rft.pages=86-97&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2017&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-100709-5&amp;rft.aulast=Michaels&amp;rft.aufirst=Axel&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DQAJCDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA86&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span><br> (d) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFFlood1996" class="citation book cs1">Flood, Gavin D. (1996). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=KpIWhKnYmF0C&amp;pg=PA35"><i>An Introduction to Hinduism</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p.&nbsp;35. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-43878-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-43878-0"><bdi>978-0-521-43878-0</bdi></a>. <q>It is this Sansrit, vedic, tradition which has maintained a continuity into modern times and which has provided the most important resource and inspiration for Hindu traditions and individuals. The Veda is the foundation for most later developments in what is known as Hinduism.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=An+Introduction+to+Hinduism&amp;rft.pages=35&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1996&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-43878-0&amp;rft.aulast=Flood&amp;rft.aufirst=Gavin+D.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DKpIWhKnYmF0C%26pg%3DPA35&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Combined-4-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Combined-4_35-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"> (a) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDyson2018" class="citation cs2">Dyson, Tim (2018), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3TRtDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA25"><i>A Population History of India: From the First Modern People to the Present Day</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>, p.&nbsp;25, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-882905-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-882905-8"><bdi>978-0-19-882905-8</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Population+History+of+India%3A+From+the+First+Modern+People+to+the+Present+Day&amp;rft.pages=25&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-882905-8&amp;rft.aulast=Dyson&amp;rft.aufirst=Tim&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D3TRtDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA25&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span>; (b) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDyson2018" class="citation cs2">Dyson, Tim (2018), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3TRtDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA16"><i>A Population History of India: From the First Modern People to the Present Day</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>, p.&nbsp;16, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-882905-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-882905-8"><bdi>978-0-19-882905-8</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Population+History+of+India%3A+From+the+First+Modern+People+to+the+Present+Day&amp;rft.pages=16&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-882905-8&amp;rft.aulast=Dyson&amp;rft.aufirst=Tim&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D3TRtDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA16&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Dyson2018-16a-36"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Dyson2018-16a_36-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

        <li id="cite_note-kashmir-disputes-63"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-kashmir-disputes_63-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">(a) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation cs2"><span class="cs1-lock-subscription" title="Paid subscription required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Kashmir-region-Indian-subcontinent">"Kashmir, region Indian subcontinent"</a></span>, <i>Encyclopaedia Britannica</i>, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20190813203817/https://www.britannica.com/place/Kashmir-region-Indian-subcontinent">archived</a> from the original on 13 August 2019<span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">15 August</span> 2019</span>, <q>Kashmir, region of the northwestern Indian subcontinent<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>... has been the subject of dispute between India and Pakistan since the partition of the Indian subcontinent in 1947.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Kashmir%2C+region+Indian+subcontinent&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopaedia+Britannica&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2Fplace%2FKashmir-region-Indian-subcontinent&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span>;<br> (b) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFPletcher" class="citation cs2">Pletcher, Kenneth, <span class="cs1-lock-subscription" title="Paid subscription required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Aksai-Chin">"Aksai Chin, Plateau Region, Asia"</a></span>, <i>Encyclopaedia Britannica</i>, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20190402090308/https://www.britannica.com/place/Aksai-Chin">archived</a> from the original on 2 April 2019<span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">16 August</span> 2019</span>, <q>Aksai Chin, Chinese (Pinyin) Aksayqin, portion of the Kashmir region, ... constitutes nearly all the territory of the Chinese-administered sector of Kashmir that is claimed by India</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Aksai+Chin%2C+Plateau+Region%2C+Asia&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopaedia+Britannica&amp;rft.aulast=Pletcher&amp;rft.aufirst=Kenneth&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2Fplace%2FAksai-Chin&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span>; <br> (c) 
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFC._E_Bosworth2006" class="citation encyclopaedia cs1">C. E Bosworth (2006). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=l_cWAQAAMAAJ&amp;pg=PA328">"Kashmir"</a>. <i>Encyclopedia Americana: Jefferson to Latin</i>. <i>Encyclopedia Americana</i>. <a href="/wiki/Scholastic_Library_Publishing" class="mw-redirect" title="Scholastic Library Publishing">Scholastic Library Publishing</a>. p.&nbsp;328. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7172-0139-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7172-0139-6"><bdi>978-0-7172-0139-6</bdi></a>. <q>KASHMIR, kash'mer, the northernmost region of the Indian subcontinent, administered partly by India, partly by Pakistan, and partly by China. The region has been the subject of a bitter dispute between India and Pakistan since they became independent in 1947</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Encyclopedia+Americana%3A+Jefferson+to+Latin&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+Americana&amp;rft.pages=328&amp;rft.pub=Scholastic+Library+Publishing&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7172-0139-6&amp;rft.au=C.+E+Bosworth&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dl_cWAQAAMAAJ%26pg%3DPA328&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

        <li id="cite_note-IUCN-India-66"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-IUCN-India_66-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-IUCN-India_66-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation cs2"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.iucn.org/asia/countries/india"><i>India</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/International_Union_for_the_Conservation_of_Nature" class="mw-redirect" title="International Union for the Conservation of Nature">International Union for the Conservation of Nature</a> (IUCN), 2019</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=India&amp;rft.pub=International+Union+for+the+Conservation+of+Nature+%28IUCN%29&amp;rft.date=2019&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.iucn.org%2Fasia%2Fcountries%2Findia&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-indiaforest-67"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-indiaforest_67-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-indiaforest_67-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-indiaforest_67-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-indiaforest_67-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-indiaforest_67-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://www.frienvis.nic.in/Database/Forest-Cover-in-States-UTs-2019_2478.aspx">http://www.frienvis.nic.in/Database/Forest-Cover-in-States-UTs-2019_2478.aspx</a></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-WoodroffeThirgood2005-68"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-WoodroffeThirgood2005_68-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFKaranthGopal2005" class="citation cs2">Karanth, K. Ullas; Gopal, Rajesh (2005), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=6vNzRzcjntAC&amp;pg=PA374">"An ecology-based policy framework for human-tiger coexistence in India"</a>, in Rosie Woodroffe; Simon Thirgood; Alan Rabinowitz (eds.), <i>People and Wildlife, Conflict Or Co-existence?</i>, <a href="/wiki/Cambridge_University_Press" title="Cambridge University Press">Cambridge University Press</a>, p.&nbsp;374, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-53203-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-53203-7"><bdi>978-0-521-53203-7</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=An+ecology-based+policy+framework+for+human-tiger+coexistence+in+India&amp;rft.btitle=People+and+Wildlife%2C+Conflict+Or+Co-existence%3F&amp;rft.pages=374&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-53203-7&amp;rft.aulast=Karanth&amp;rft.aufirst=K.+Ullas&amp;rft.au=Gopal%2C+Rajesh&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D6vNzRzcjntAC%26pg%3DPA374&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-69"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-69">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation cs2"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.oed.com/view/Entry/94384#eid677811"><i>India (noun)</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary" title="Oxford English Dictionary">Oxford English Dictionary</a>, 3rd Edition, 2009</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=India+%28noun%29&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+English+Dictionary%2C+3rd+Edition&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.oed.com%2Fview%2FEntry%2F94384%23eid677811&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span> (subscription required)</span> </li>

          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFThieme1970" class="citation cs2">Thieme, P.         <li id="cite_note-Clementin-Ojha-72"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Clementin-Ojha_72-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Clementin-Ojha_72-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Clementin-Ojha_72-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

        <li id="cite_note-Jha2014-74"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Jha2014_74-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFJha2014" class="citation cs2">Jha, Dwijendra Narayan (2014), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=dqDgBQAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA11"><i>Rethinking Hindu Identity</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Routledge" title="Routledge">Routledge</a>, p.&nbsp;11, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-317-49034-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-317-49034-0"><bdi>978-1-317-49034-0</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Rethinking+Hindu+Identity&amp;rft.pages=11&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-317-49034-0&amp;rft.aulast=Jha&amp;rft.aufirst=Dwijendra+Narayan&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DdqDgBQAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA11&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Singh2017-75"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Singh2017_75-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

        <li id="cite_note-Barrow-76"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Barrow_76-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Barrow_76-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBarrow2003" class="citation journal cs1">Barrow, Ian J. (2003). "From Hindustan to India: Naming change in changing names". <i>South Asia: Journal of South Asian Studies</i>. <b>26</b> (1): 37–49. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1080%2F085640032000063977">10.1080/085640032000063977</a>. <a href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:144039519">144039519</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=South+Asia%3A+Journal+of+South+Asian+Studies&amp;rft.atitle=From+Hindustan+to+India%3A+Naming+change+in+changing+names&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=37-49&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1080%2F085640032000063977&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A144039519%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.aulast=Barrow&amp;rft.aufirst=Ian+J.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEEncyclopædia_Britannica-77"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEncyclopædia_Britannica_77-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFEncyclopædia_Britannica">Encyclopædia Britannica</a>.</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Lowe2015-78"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Lowe2015_78-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFLowe2015" class="citation book cs1">Lowe, John J. (2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=L07CBwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA2"><i>Participles in Rigvedic Sanskrit: The syntax and semantics of adjectival verb forms</i></a>. Oxford University Press. pp.&nbsp;1–2. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-100505-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-100505-3"><bdi>978-0-19-100505-3</bdi></a>. <q>It consists of 1,028 hymns (suktas), highly crafted poetic compositions originally intended for recital during rituals and for the invocation of and communication with the Indo-Aryan gods. Modern scholarly opinion largely agrees that these hymns were composed between around 1500&nbsp;BCE and 1200&nbsp;BCE, during the eastward migration of the Indo-Aryan tribes from the mountains of what is today northern Afghanistan across the Punjab into north India.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Participles+in+Rigvedic+Sanskrit%3A+The+syntax+and+semantics+of+adjectival+verb+forms&amp;rft.pages=1-2&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-100505-3&amp;rft.aulast=Lowe&amp;rft.aufirst=John+J.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DL07CBwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA2&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Lowe2017-epic-79"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Lowe2017-epic_79-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFLowe2017" class="citation book cs1">Lowe, John J. (2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=nSgmDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA58"><i>Transitive Nouns and Adjectives: Evidence from Early Indo-Aryan</i></a>. Oxford University Press. p.&nbsp;58. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-879357-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-879357-1"><bdi>978-0-19-879357-1</bdi></a>. <q>The term ‘Epic Sanskrit’ refers to the language of the two great Sanskrit epics, the Mahābhārata and the Rāmāyaṇa. ... It is likely, therefore, that the epic-like elements found in Vedic sources and the two epics that we have are not directly related, but that both drew on the same source, an oral tradition of storytelling that existed before, throughout, and after the Vedic period.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Transitive+Nouns+and+Adjectives%3A+Evidence+from+Early+Indo-Aryan&amp;rft.pages=58&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2017&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-879357-1&amp;rft.aulast=Lowe&amp;rft.aufirst=John+J.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DnSgmDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA58&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Dyson2018-80"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Dyson2018_80-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDyson2018" class="citation cs2">Dyson, Tim (2018), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3TRtDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA1"><i>A Population History of India: From the First Modern People to the Present Day</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>, p.&nbsp;1, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-882905-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-882905-8"><bdi>978-0-19-882905-8</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Population+History+of+India%3A+From+the+First+Modern+People+to+the+Present+Day&amp;rft.pages=1&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-882905-8&amp;rft.aulast=Dyson&amp;rft.aufirst=Tim&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D3TRtDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA1&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span> Quote: "Modern human beings—<i>Homo sapiens</i>—originated in Africa. Then, intermittently, sometime between 60,000 and 80,000 years ago, tiny groups of them began to enter the north-west of the Indian subcontinent. It seems likely that initially they came by way of the coast. ... it is virtually certain that there were <i>Homo sapiens</i> in the subcontinent 55,000 years ago, even though the earliest fossils that have been found of them date to only about 30,000 years before the present. (page 1)"</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-PetragliaAllchin-81"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-PetragliaAllchin_81-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMichael_D._PetragliaBridget_Allchin2007" class="citation book cs1">Michael D. Petraglia; <a href="/wiki/Bridget_Allchin" title="Bridget Allchin">Bridget Allchin</a> (22 May 2007). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Qm9GfjNlnRwC&amp;pg=PA10"><i>The Evolution and History of Human Populations in South Asia: Inter-disciplinary Studies in Archaeology, Biological Anthropology, Linguistics and Genetics</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Springer_Science_%2B_Business_Media" class="mw-redirect" title="Springer Science + Business Media">Springer Science + Business Media</a>. p.&nbsp;6. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4020-5562-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4020-5562-1"><bdi>978-1-4020-5562-1</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Evolution+and+History+of+Human+Populations+in+South+Asia%3A+Inter-disciplinary+Studies+in+Archaeology%2C+Biological+Anthropology%2C+Linguistics+and+Genetics&amp;rft.pages=6&amp;rft.pub=Springer+Science+%2B+Business+Media&amp;rft.date=2007-05-22&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4020-5562-1&amp;rft.au=Michael+D.+Petraglia&amp;rft.au=Bridget+Allchin&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DQm9GfjNlnRwC%26pg%3DPA10&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span> Quote: "Y-Chromosome and Mt-DNA data support the colonization of South Asia by modern humans originating in Africa. ... Coalescence dates for most non-European populations average to between 73–55 ka."</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Fisher2018-82"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Fisher2018_82-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFFisher2018" class="citation cs2">Fisher, Michael H. (2018), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=kZVuDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA23"><i>An Environmental History of India: From Earliest Times to the Twenty-First Century</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Cambridge_University_Press" title="Cambridge University Press">Cambridge University Press</a>, p.&nbsp;23, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-107-11162-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-107-11162-2"><bdi>978-1-107-11162-2</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=An+Environmental+History+of+India%3A+From+Earliest+Times+to+the+Twenty-First+Century&amp;rft.pages=23&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-107-11162-2&amp;rft.aulast=Fisher&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael+H.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DkZVuDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA23&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span> Quote: "Scholars estimate that the first successful expansion of the <i>Homo sapiens</i> range beyond Africa and across the Arabian Peninsula occurred from as early as 80,000 years ago to as late as 40,000 years ago, although there may have been prior unsuccessful emigrations. Some of their descendants extended the human range ever further in each generation, spreading into each habitable land they encountered. One human channel was along the warm and productive coastal lands of the Persian Gulf and northern Indian Ocean. Eventually, various bands entered India between 75,000 years ago and 35,000 years ago (page 23)"</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEPetragliaAllchin20076-83"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPetragliaAllchin20076_83-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPetragliaAllchin2007">Petraglia &amp; Allchin 2007</a>, p.&nbsp;6.</span> </li>

        <li id="cite_note-Jha2018-198"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Jha2018_198-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Jha2018_198-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Jha2018_198-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Jha2018_198-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

        <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTETritsch2001-199"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTETritsch2001_199-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTETritsch2001_199-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTETritsch2001_199-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTETritsch2001_199-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTETritsch2001_199-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFTritsch2001">Tritsch 2001</a>.</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Goyal2006-200"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Goyal2006_200-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFGoyal2006" class="citation cs2">Goyal, Anupam (2006), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=UTGQAAAAMAAJ&amp;pg=PA295"><i>The WTO and International Environmental Law: Towards Conciliation</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>, p.&nbsp;295, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-567710-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-567710-2"><bdi>978-0-19-567710-2</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+WTO+and+International+Environmental+Law%3A+Towards+Conciliation&amp;rft.pages=295&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-567710-2&amp;rft.aulast=Goyal&amp;rft.aufirst=Anupam&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DUTGQAAAAMAAJ%26pg%3DPA295&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span> Quote: "The Indian government successfully argued that the medicinal <i>neem</i> tree is part of traditional Indian knowledge. (page 295)"</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Hughes2013-201"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Hughes2013_201-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHughes2013" class="citation cs2">Hughes, Julie E. (2013), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=RL8qWNmpkc0C&amp;pg=PT106"><i>Animal Kingdoms</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University_Press" title="Harvard University Press">Harvard University Press</a>, p.&nbsp;106, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-674-07480-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-674-07480-4"><bdi>978-0-674-07480-4</bdi></a>, <q>At same time, the leafy pipal trees and comparative abundance that marked the Mewari landscape fostered refinements unattainable in other lands.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Animal+Kingdoms&amp;rft.pages=106&amp;rft.pub=Harvard+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-674-07480-4&amp;rft.aulast=Hughes&amp;rft.aufirst=Julie+E.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DRL8qWNmpkc0C%26pg%3DPT106&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-AmeriCostello2018-202"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-AmeriCostello2018_202-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAmeriCostelloJamison2018" class="citation cs2">Ameri, Marta; Costello, Sarah Kielt; Jamison, Gregg; Scott, Sarah Jarmer (2018), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=SklVDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA156"><i>Seals and Sealing in the Ancient World: Case Studies from the Near East, Egypt, the Aegean, and South Asia</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Cambridge_University_Press" title="Cambridge University Press">Cambridge University Press</a>, pp.&nbsp;156–157, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-108-17351-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-108-17351-3"><bdi>978-1-108-17351-3</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Seals+and+Sealing+in+the+Ancient+World%3A+Case+Studies+from+the+Near+East%2C+Egypt%2C+the+Aegean%2C+and+South+Asia&amp;rft.pages=156-157&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-108-17351-3&amp;rft.aulast=Ameri&amp;rft.aufirst=Marta&amp;rft.au=Costello%2C+Sarah+Kielt&amp;rft.au=Jamison%2C+Gregg%3B+Scott%2C+Sarah+Jarmer&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DSklVDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA156&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span> Quote: "The last of the centaurs has the long, wavy, horizontal horns of a markhor, a human face, a heavy-set body that appears bovine, and a goat tail ... This figure is often depicted by itself, but it is also consistently represented in scenes that seem to reflect the adoration of a figure in a pipal tree or arbour and which may be termed ritual. These include fully detailed scenes like that visible in the large 'divine adoration' seal from Mohenjo-daro."</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Gwynne2011-203"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Gwynne2011_203-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

        <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEHawksworthTiwari2011-319"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHawksworthTiwari2011_319-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHawksworthTiwari2011_319-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHawksworthTiwari2011_319-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHawksworthTiwari2011">Hawksworth &amp; Tiwari 2011</a>.</span> </li>
